Planned Parenthood sent out an email fundraiser letter to supporters Wednesday announcing that a third woman, Julie Swetnick, is accusing Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh of sexual misconduct.ìEnough is enough: Kavanaugh must withdraw now,î writes Dawn Laguens, executive vice president of Planned Parenthood Action Fund, in an email made available to Breitbart News.She continues:Moving forward with Kavanaughís nomination at this point would be irresponsible and dangerous.†It tells survivors of sexual assault that they donít matter. It tells the public that one manís promotion matters more than the safety of multiple women. And it sends a message that partisan politics trumps not only fairness, but basic human compassion.Speak out now: This nomination is a disgrace. Brett Kavanaugh must withdraw.ì[T]ogether, funneling our hurt and our anger into action, weíll stop this nomination from going any further,î Laguens adds.The fundraising letter comes with a ìtrigger warningî as well: ìThis message includes information about sexual assault.†If you are finding it difficult to hear about sexual violence in the media and online, remember to take care of yourself.îQuestions, however, arose†quickly about Swetnickís accusations after it was discovered that she would have been a college student during the period of time she claims Kavanaugh was ìpresentî at gang rapes during high school parties.Breitbart News reported:On Wednesday morning, Michael Avenatti, the aspiring presidential candidate and lawyer for porn star Stormy Daniels, released a sworn affidavit from Swetnick in which she claimed to have met Kavanaugh and his friend Mark Judge in ìapproximately 1980-1981.îShe then went on to claim that in 1981-82, she ìbecame aware of effortsî by Kavanaugh, Judge, and others to ìspikeî the punch ìat house parties I attendedî with the intent of incapacitating a girl who could then be gang raped. She said she witnessed Kavanaugh and Judge lining up outside a room waiting for their ìturn.î She also said that in 1982, she was a victim of such gang rape, while drugged, with Kavanaugh and Judge ìpresent.îHowever, according to her resumÈ, Swetnick graduated from Gaithersburg High School in 1980 prior to attending the University of Maryland. Kavanaugh graduated from Georgetown Prep in 1983. These details indicate Swetnick would have known Kavanaugh while she was 17 or 18, and he was 15 or 16 years old and that she was attending high school parties while she was a college student.

The Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday released a lightly redacted copy of the transcript of Mondayís conference call between Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett Kavanaugh and committee staff.The call, conducted under threat of criminal penalty for lying, reveals an exasperated Kavanaugh countering accusation after accusation, likening his situation to an episode of The Twilight Zone.The transcript reveals previously unknown details and one heretofore unrevealed accusation involving Kavanaugh and a man, suggested to be Mark Judge, sexually assaulting a woman on a boat off the coast of Newport, Rhode Island, in 1985, only to be confronted the next morning by two men who then severely beat Kavanaugh and Judge.This new fifth accuser, according to the Senate Judiciary Committee staffer on the call, conveyed his allegations by telephone on Monday to Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse (D-RI). The staffer then read Whitehouseís officeís report over the phone:Senator Whitehouse received a call this morning from a Rhode Island constituent, [REDACTED], who made allegations regarding U.S. Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh. [REDACTED] reported that early on a Sunday morning in August of 1985, a close acquaintance of the constituent was sexually assaulted by two heavily inebriated men she referred to at the time as Brett and Mark.The event took place on a 36-foot maroon and white boat in the harbor at Newport, Rhode Island, after the three had met at a local bar. According to [REDACTED], when he learned of the assault at approximately 5:00 a.m. that same morning, he and another individual went to the harbor, located the boat the victim had described and physically confronted the two men, leaving them with significant injuries.[REDACTED] recently realized that one of the men was Brett Kavanaugh when he saw Kavanaughís high school yearbook photo on television over the weekend. Harvard Law School emeritus professor and celebrated defense lawyer Alan Dershowitz told Breitbart News on Wednesday evening that the affidavit by Julie Swetnick, the third woman to accuse Judge Brett Kavanaugh of sexual misconduct in high school, ìdoes not ring true.îSwetnick presented a sworn affidavit on Wednesday through her lawyer, Michael Avenatti ó who is also representing porn star Stormy Daniels in her litigation against President Donald Trump, and is exploring a presidential run in 2020 himself.ìAny reasonably competent [defense] attorney could demolish her affidavit,î Dershowitz said, noting that Swetnick had not explained what she meant when she alleged that Kavanaugh was ìpresentî at her gang rape.He also said that she had failed to explain why, if she had witnessed multiple gang rapes at parties among Kavanaughís friends in Maryland, she had kept going back to the parties.The affidavit looked as if it had been prepared in haste, Dershowitz said, as Avenatti likely realized he needed to publish it before Thursdayís hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee if it were to have any impact on the confirmation process.(Kavanaugh is scheduled to testify, along with the first accuser, Christine Blasey Ford, whose claims have not been corroborated by any of the eyewitnesses she named.)Swetnick had mentioned two eyewitnesses, Dershowitz noted, but had not named them. ìAny lawyer should have been embarrassed to submit an affidavit like that.îHe criticized the Republican majority on the judiciary committee, however, for selecting Arizona prosecutor†Rachel Mitchell to lead questioning on Thursday. They should have named a defense attorney instead, he argued.ìWhat does a prosecutor know about cross-examintion? A prosecutor puts on a case.îJoel B. Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-UT) said on Wednesday that he believes the 11th-hour charges of sexual misconduct leveled against Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh are ìunfairî to him and the confirmation process.Just days after more than 30 hours of hearings where Kavanaugh was questioned by both Democrats and Republicans and years after extensive vetting for his confirmation to the federal judiciary, three women have come forward with claims of sexual encounters with him in the 1980s.ìItís amazing to me that these type of things have come up way after the fact, way after the end of the committee hearings and everything else,î Hatch said in a statement. ìIt shows that there are people who would stop at nothing.îìI donít think itís fair to Brett Kavanaugh, I donít think itís fair to our system, I donít think itís fair to the process,î Hatch said. ìI donít think we should put up with it, to be honest.îChristine Blasey Ford delivered a letter to Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-CA) in July claiming Kavanaugh groped her at a high school party, but Feinstein did not make the letter public until after the confirmation hearings.Feinstein also never brought the subject up when she met with Kavanaugh.Deborah Ramirez and Julie Swetnick have also come forward, each with worsening accusations of Kavanaugh exposing himself and drugging womenís drinks and participating in multiple ìgang rapes,î respectively.The Senate Judiciary Committee, which has scheduled a vote on Kavanaugh for Friday, is set to hear from Ford at a hearing on Thursday. I donít understand how her lawyer didnít go immediately to the police, and back then why people wouldnít have said something. We understand why women donít generally report sexual assault and they often donít talk about it for a long time, but this a quantum leap different. This is a frightening allegation that there were groups of boys with groups of girls over two years involved in drinking, drugs and gang rape. And no one ever went to the police, no one has gone to the police to this day to report those allegations? Itís truly outrageous.TUR: Are you calling her a liar?WILKINSON: Iím not calling her a liar. If this is true, it is a horrible thing. Thereís nothing that could have stopped Mr. Avenatti from going to the FBI or the police to start an investigation on his own. As far as I can tell from reading this, that wasnít done.TUR: All the women who have accused your client of misconduct have one similar thing in common. They all say he drank to excess. There are other folks out there from his high school years and from his college years who say the same thing, he drank to excess. Your client also admits he did at some times have a few too many beers. If thatís the case and if thereís a potential out there for him being black out drunk or very drunk, how is he confident of his memories?WILKINSON: First of all, almost every high school and college student could be accused of the same thing or have done, had drinks, had too many drinks. Thatís not the same as being black out drunk and not remembering this. He knows that he didnít know this woman. Sheís not saying itís once. Sheís saying itís over two years. This wasnít a one time thing. Thatís the same with the other two women. All the people who are supposedly there in those instances have said it didnít happen or they donít have any recollection. Thereís not one person who is saying they were there. In each of the incidents thereís groups of people that were identified as present. Thatís not typical in these allegations. Normally itís one man and one woman and itís hard to determine. Here, especially in the most recent outrageous allegation, thereís scores of people involved for years.TUR: Why is your client not demanding an FBI investigation to get to the bottom of this?WILKINSON: He didnít know about this until it came out today. Mr. Avenatti has had this information for weeks.TUR: Is he now demanding an FBI investigation?WILKINSON: He knows he didnít do it.TUR: Why doesnít he want an FBI investigation? If thereís multiple people who can go on the record or go under oath or be interviewed by the FB, why would he not want the FBI to get involved?WILKINSON: Thankfully our system doesnít work the way youíre suggesting.TUR: This is a job interview. Itís two different things.WILKINSON: Itís out here in the public opinion and what youíre doing is a perfect example. Youíre claiming because he was drinking, he must have done it.TUR: I asked you about his memory. Donít put words in my mouth. I asked if he was confident of his memories. Thatís all I asked.WILKINSON: I heard your last session and you were saying thereís so much detail. Thereís no detail in here. Thereís no place. Thereís one or two years generally. Thereís no other people. Thereís no dates. Thereís no times. Thereís no information. There are multiple people supposedly involved within several years, not just her. She saw other women being gang raped and itís never been reported. I donít know what the lawyer did and I feel sorry for her for getting dragged into this and any other woman getting dragged into it but that doesnít mean the accusations are true. This is a horrible commentary on our process this is what weíre putting people through who wants to be in public service. Itís important to treat everybody in the process with dignity and giving them the presumption of innocence whether youíre inside a courtroom or outside.TUR: Let me read you something the president said about this this morning. ëYou donít find people like this. Heís outstanding. Heís a gem and heís being treated unfairly by the Democrats who are playing a con game. They laugh at what they are getting away with.í Does your client believe itís a con game by the Democrats? The plight of Brett Kavanaugh ñ presumed guilty of sexual misconduct based solely on a womanís accusation and without due process ñ has been experienced by many young men on college campuses since the Obama administration utilized Title IX to enact its campus sexual assault policies.ìWhat has been happening to young men on college campuses is now playing out on the national stage with Judge Kavanaugh,î retired university administrator Patricia Daugherty told Breitbart News. ìIncredible money and ëtrainingí have gone into efforts to immediately side with the accuser, with little to no interest in due process for the accused. The fever pitch we see on the news has been nurtured in college.îThe Trump administrationís anticipated new rules reversing the Obama-era policies are, in fact, causing a feminist meltdown.At The Mary Sue, Chelsea Steiner†warned†that Education Secretary Betsy DeVos ìwants to protect everyone involved in sexual misconduct EXCEPT the victims.îìThe education secretary, who has endorsed a policy of using mediation to reach informal resolutions in cases of campus assault, wants to allow victims and their accused perpetrators to request any evidence they want from each other,î Steiner said, explaining her alarm. ìIn addition, victims and perpetrators would be able to cross-examine each other during the mediation.îDaugherty, who currently is president of Eagle Forum of Georgia, said parentsí concerns for their sons on college campuses are ìcompletely rational in this climate.îìWe are doing a terrible disservice to young men and also to young women by encouraging such emotional, fear-based atmospheres,î she added.In September 2017, DeVos announced the Trump administration would be scrapping the Obama administrationís policies regarding cases of sexual misconduct on college campuses. DeVos†stressed†in a new ìinterim Q & Aî that all students must be protected from discrimination in school proceedings to investigate sexual assault allegations.In her announcement, DeVos cited cases of students, nearly all male, who were either expelled or punished in some other manner after being accused of actions which were never proven.ìInstead of working with schools,î DeVos said, ìthe prior administration weaponized the Office for Civil Rights.îThe Trump administrationís proposed new rules were†leaked†to the†New York Times†at the end of August. While Liz Hill, a spokeswoman for the Education Department, said the information leaked to the†Times†ìis premature and speculative,î the newspaper reported the rules ìnarrow the definition of sexual harassment, holding schools accountable only for formal complaints filed through proper authorities and for conduct said to have occurred on their campuses.îMany college and university officials have said they will ignore the new campus rules put forward by the Trump administration.Pennsylvania Attorney General Josh Shapiro ñ now known for releasing a grand jury report alleging†at least 1,000 children were sexually abused by Roman Catholic clergy in his state over 70 years ñ condemned the Trump administrationís decision to scrap the Obama-era sexual misconduct policies.Shapiro said reversing the Obama administrationís policies ìthreaten to make college campuses less safe, not more safe.îìWe made important strides over the last years of the Obama administration when it comes to Title IX issues,î Shapiro said, according to TribLive. ìAnd the idea that Secretary Betsy DeVos would want to roll back those Title IX (civil rights) protections is something that does not sit well with me.îìI have all the confidence in the world in our university leaders of Pennsylvania,î Shapiro added. ìTheyíll fill the gap created by the Trump administrationís wrong-headed policies.îJoy Pullmann, executive editor at†the Federalist, told Breitbart News the ideology behind the implementation of the Obama-era policies on campuses sparked the fire that has spread across the nation.ìIt has always been true but is now becoming obvious to more Americans that what happens on campuses does not stay on campuses, or only affect the minority of Americans with college degrees,î she explained. ìU.S. colleges and universities create the ideas, atmosphere, and policies that affect the nation, plus the nationís taxpayers underwrite the bulk of our eliteís credentials through these institutions, and this is why everyone should care and raise his or her voice about what happens there.îìObamaís Title IX rules that amped up campus kangaroo courts were quite clearly a test run of the kind of sexist mob attacks they want to bring to the entire culture,î Pullmann added. ìThe effects are to degrade society by degrading justice itself, by reducing it to identity politics rather than the truth of what happened.îDaugherty said while she is encouraged by the Trump administrationís plans to reverse the Obama Title IX policy, she anticipates a continued battle.ìThat in itself wonít change the emphasis on todayís college campuses,î she warned. ìWay too many faculty and administrators are devoted to far-left political ideologies, and they are teaching these ideologies to their students every day.îParents of sons may continue to have reason to be concerned that liberal university pushback against the Trump administrationís new rules will still place young men, in particular, in danger of false accusations with minimal recourse.ìParents need to teach their sons to treat everyone with respect and dignity, but their sons canít be naÔve,î Daugherty said. ìI donít want them to be suspicious of all women, of course, but they need to be aware of not getting into situations that might come back to haunt them.îWriting at the Federalist, Melissa Danford, an army wife and mother of four boys, said what she is seeing now should stir parents of sons to rise up.ìI cannot accept a world in which my sons will be raised under the tyranny of a lawless, vindictive society that wants to subdue and oppress men in the name of equality for women,î she said. ìThe future isnít female; it belongs to both your daughters†and†my sons. Abandoning the basic standards of the rule of law will not empower women; it will enslave us all.îPullmann agreed it is ìquite rational for mothers to wonder whether their sons will be discriminated against simply because of their sex.îìGiven that we have not only seen high-profile assault hoaxes ñ such as Columbiaís ëmattress girlí and the UVA Rolling Stone hoax ñ but also a litany of lower-profile incidents on campuses throughout the country, some of which are being litigated in real courts due to the egregiously unjust outcomes,î she added.The†Daily Newsís editorial board also†said†due process is exactly what is needed to put an end to the ìkangaroo courtsî that have erupted on college campuses:Today, the accused have no way to see the evidence against them, no way to appeal. Tomorrow, they are likely to be able to cross-examine accusers, and vice versa.ÖThe hands wringing that fair procedures will terrify young women out of reporting serious violations ought to be applauding efforts to make Title IX a credible tool to vindicate victims.Pullmann added traditional sexual morality actually protects both men and women from sexual misconduct allegations and misconduct towards each other.ìBoth men and women should not have sex, or sexually charged interactions, with strangers while drunk,î she asserted. ìEven without alcohol, sex without a marital commitment puts both the man and the woman in danger, not only of accusations but of being mistreated sexually by someone who doesnít love them enough to commit to them for life.îPullmann advised parents to explicitly teach their sons ìnot to trivialize sex, but to regard it, and therefore women, as precious.îìSince neither our culture nor most educational institutions will do this ó sometimes not even churches ó parents must take the task upon themselves all the more if they want to protect both their sons and their daughters from the brutalities of our hookup culture,î she said.

column3:
All ten Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee signed a letter Wednesday demanding that President Donald Trump withdraw the nomination of Judge Brett Kavanaugh to the U.S. Supreme Court.Citing ìmultiple allegations of sexual assaultî ó those of Christine Blasey Ford (Kavanaugh groping at high school party), Deborah Ramirez (Kavanaugh exposing himself at college party), and Julie Swetnick (Kavanaugh present at gang rapes in high school) ó all of which Kavanaugh denies, and none of which has been corroborated ó Democrats asked Trump to ìimmediately direct an FBI investigation or withdraw this nomination.îAll 10 Democratic members of Senate Judiciary Cmte. call for President Trump to ìimmediately withdrawî Kavanaugh nomination, or direct the FBI to re-open its background investigation and ìthoroughly examine the multiple allegations of sexual assault.î pic.twitter.com/pU6C98xPiNó NBC News (@NBCNews) September 26, 2018In the letter, Democrats also refer to Fordís accusations as ìcredible,î though they have been contradicted by the four witnesses she has named as being there. They refer to the other accusations as ìconsistent,î though Ramirezís claims were also denied by all of the eyewitnesses.It was not clear from the letter whether Democrats would still participate in Thursdayís scheduled hearing, where Ford and Kavanaugh are expected to testify under oath, and the judge ó who has served for twelve years on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ó is expected to deny Fordís accusations and others that have emerged.On Wednesday, Swetnickís claims were presented by lawyer and presidential hopeful Michael Avenatti, who also represents porn star Stormy Daniels is a defamation suit against Trump that a federal judge seems poised to dismiss.The signatories to Wednesdayís letter include Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-CT), who falsely claimed to have served in Vietnam, and by Sen. Cory Booker (D-NJ), who admitted during college that he had groped a girl in high school without her consent.All of the claims emerged after confirmation hearings, and after ranking member Sen. Dianne Feinstein had concealed Fordís uncorroborated claim since July.Joel B. Pollak is Senior Editor-at-Large at Breitbart News. He is a winner of the 2018 Robert Novak Journalism Alumni Fellowship. He is also the co-author of†How Trump Won: The Inside Story of a Revolution, which is available from Regnery. Follow him on Twitter at @joelpollak.

Actress Alyssa Milano and other activists demanded that staffers of Senator Cindy Hyde-Smith (R-MS) ìopen the door!î to ìhear the stories!î on Capitol Hill on Wednesday.The ì#Womentowomenî protesters†aim to ìtalk women to womenî with female Republican senators about their opposition to President Donald Trumpís Supreme Court Justice nominee Judge Brett Kavanaugh and to share their stories of sexual assault.ì[Hyde-Smithís staff] seemed to be smirking and on their phones and they then just went back into their office and closed the door,î one protester can be heard saying, upset that staffers locked themselves into a separate part of their office. ìAnd the gentleman who said he was going to find out just sort of snuck in and grabbed something and left.îWatch Full-Length Video:The protesters, led by Milano, engaged in several different chants: ìOpen the door! Hear the stories!î ìOpen your heart! Hear the stories!î ìHave you no heart? Hear the stories!îìWe will not be silenced any longer!!!!î one protester screamed.Iím in D.C.  because I donít believe any manís misogyny should take precedent over a survivorís humanity. We tried to see a Murkowski, Collins and Hyde-Smith today and share our stories of survival. They refused to see us. #KavaNo #BelieveWomen #SurvivorStrong pic.twitter.com/rRtTSVWEpJó Alyssa Milano (@Alyssa_Milano) September 26, 2018According to the senatorís office, however, the decision to move the staffers was made due to the disruption caused by the protesters.ìProtestors filled the front office, chanting and disturbing the operations of staff managing the front desks. The Chief of Staff simply moved the staff assistants to an office where they could continue to answer phones undisturbed,î Hyde-Smithís office wrote in an email to Breitbart News.ìThe front office was left open with Capitol Police and Senior Staff monitoring. The protestors chanted their piece and left. Senator Hyde-Smith enjoys hearing from her constituents and their wide variety of their opinions. The Senator, however, does not look fondly on protesters who disrupt her constituents and the office operations.îWe are talking #WomenToWomen. Sharing our stories with Senators about why we need them to #VoteNo #KavaNO https://t.co/2q02Af6xIXó Alyssa Milano (@Alyssa_Milano) September 26, 2018Time we talk woman to woman. Women, survivors & allies will be showing up to the offices of Senate Republican women to share our stories.  I will be there. Will you join me?ErnstCollinsMurkowski Hyde-Smith Fischer Capito #BelieveWomen #CancelKavanaugh #WomanToWoman pic.twitter.com/GyWjajUZetó Alyssa Milano (@Alyssa_Milano) September 25, 2018†Breitbart Newsí Matthew Perdie contributed to this article.Amanda House is Breitbart Newsí Deputy Political Editor. You can follow her on Twitter at†@AmandaLeeHouse†and†Instagram.†

The following statement is Brett Kavanaughís prepared written testimony, which the Supreme Court nominee will deliver in a Thursday Senate Judiciary Committee hearing:Mr. Chairman, Ranking Member Feinstein, and Members of the Committee:Eleven days ago, Dr. Ford publicly accused me of committing a serious wrong more than 36 years ago when we were both in high school. I denied the allegation immediately, unequivocally, and categorically. The next day, I told this Committee that I wanted to testify as soon as possible, under oath, to clear my name.Over the past few days, other false and uncorroborated accusations have been aired. There has been a frenzy to come up with somethingóanything, no matter how far-fetched or odiousóthat will block a vote on my nomination. These are last-minute smears, pure and simple. They debase our public discourse. And the consequences extend beyond any one nomination. Such grotesque and obvious character assassinationóif allowed to succeedówill dissuade competent and good people of all political persuasions from serving our country.As I told this Committee the last time I appeared before you, a federal judge must be independent, not swayed by public or political pressure. That is the kind of judge I am and will always be. I will not be intimidated into withdrawing from this process. This effort to destroy my good name will not drive me out. The vile threats of violence against my family will not drive me out. I am here this morning to answer these allegations and to tell the truth. And the truth is that I have never sexually assaulted anyoneónot in high school, not in college, not ever.Sexual assault is horrific. It is morally wrong. It is illegal. It is contrary to my religious faith. And it contradicts the core promise of this Nation that all people are created equal and entitled to be treated with dignity and respect. Allegations of sexual assault must be taken seriously. Those who make allegations deserve to be heard. The subject of allegations also deserves to be heard. Due process is a foundation of the American rule of law.Dr. Fordís allegation dates back more than 36 years, to a party that she says occurred during our time in high school. I spent most of my time in high school focused on academics, sports, church, and service. But I was not perfect in those days, just as I am not perfect today. I drank beer with my friends, usually on weekends. Sometimes I had too many. In retrospect, I said and did things in high school that make me cringe now. But thatís not why we are here today. What Iíve† been accused of is far more serious than juvenile misbehavior. I never did anything remotely resembling what Dr. Ford describes.The allegation of misconduct is completely inconsistent with the rest of my life. The record of my life, from my days in grade school through the present day, shows that I have always promoted the equality and dignity of women.I categorically and unequivocally deny the allegation against me by Dr. Ford. I never had any sexual or physical encounter of any kind with Dr. Ford. I am not questioning that Dr. Ford may have been sexually assaulted by some person in some place at some time. But I have never done that to her or to anyone. I am innocent of this charge.

Wednesday on ABCís ìThe View,î attorney Michael Avenatti called in to discuss his client†Julie Swetnickís allegations against†Supreme Court associate justice nominee Brett Kavanaugh.Avenatti said, ìMoments ago, we sent a sworn declaration under penalty of perjury signed by my client, Julie Swetnick, detailing her allegations against Brett Kavanaugh, Mark Judge and others relating to the early í80s and what she observed and witnessed, as well as what transpired to her during that time period. We have asked the committee, as we did days ago, to launch a formal FBI investigation. My client is ready to meet with FBI agents to disclose what she knows in detail. We have also offered that sheíll take a polygraph exam if Brett Kavanaugh will take a polygraph exam. And let me also say that Iím looking forward to anyone attempting to challenge the credibility of my client, because she is absolutely credible. She is a very brave woman, and in fact, she has also obtained multiple security clearances issued by the U.S. government over many, many years.îHe continued, ìIf you read further in the declaration, are far more specific relating to Brett Kavanaughís conduct toward women in general, including the attempts to drug women by placing grain alcohol and/or drugs in the punch of many of these parties. Many of these women ended up gang raped, unfortunately. The details are specific. They are shocking. But above all else they are true. And my client stands behind them 100%, and sheís looking forward to having an opportunity to meet with one or more FBI agents hopefully, and describe what happened, and sheís also prepared to testify, if sheís permitted to do so, to the U.S. Senate. But under no circumstances should Brett Kavanaugh be confirmed to the U.S. Supreme Court until these allegations and others are vetted and all of the facts and the truth are known. You know, Brett Kavanaugh went on Fox a couple days ago and he stated that he wanted an opportunity to be heard. Well, heís had an opportunity to be heard. He can certainly have an opportunity to be heard further by the FBI and others. I want my client to have an opportunity to be heard. I want Dr. Ford to have an opportunity to be heard. And I want the corroborating witnesses to have an opportunity to be heard.îHe added, ìShe is willing to testify. Again, sheís willing to meet with the FBI forthwith immediately to describe what she witnessed. Sheís prepared to provide additional corroborating witnessesí names to the FBI associated with that investigation, and weíre hopeful that the committee is going to respond immediately by calling for an FBI investigation so that all of these allegations can be properly vetted and the truth can be known.îFollow Pam Key on Twitter @pamkeyNEN

Twitter has refused to uphold its harassment rules†against an Antifa account which encouraged harassment of Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX), after permanently blacklisting Infowars host Alex Jones last month based on the same rules. Following the publishing of this article, Twitter admitted the tweets were ìviolating our rules against abusive behavior,î but the post featuring a video of Sen. Cruz being harassed remains on the site.ìSmash Racism DC,î an account which openly supports Antifa and the abolition of U.S. Immigration Customs and Enforcement, uploaded a video of left-wing activists harassing Cruz and his wife at a restaurant this week.ìCruz has been friends with creep Kavanaugh for 20 years. Now Cruz is on judiciary committee hearing his testimony. Fascists not welcome!î the group captioned the video, receiving over 30,000 likes and 12,000 retweets.https://twitter.com/SmashRacismDC/status/1044408830564683776According to Twitterís rules, the social network†prohibits ìbehavior that crosses the line into abuse, including behavior that harasses, intimidates, or uses fear to silence another userís voice,î however the video remains, despite the fact that Infowarsí Alex Jones was banned from Twitter this month for a similar video in which he filmed himself berating CNN reporter Oliver Darcy.ìToday, we permanently suspended @realalexjones and @infowars from Twitter and Periscope. We took this action based on new reports of Tweets and videos posted yesterday that violate our abusive behavior policy, in addition to the accountsí past violations,î declared Twitter this month. ìAs we continue to increase transparency around our rules and enforcement actions, we wanted to be open about this action given the broad interest in this case.îTwitter currently has hundreds of Antifa and openly pro-Antifa accounts on the social network, even though the group has been registered as a†domestic terrorist group in the United States.
Twitter also claimed last year that they would ìtake enforcement action against organizations that use/have historically used violence as a means to advance their cause,î but have refused to take action against pro-Antifa accounts.Following the publication of this article, Twitter did admit that the Antifa tweets were ìviolating our rules against abusive behavior,î however the tweet in this article remains on the site and no action appears to have been taken.The social network did not reply to a request for comment from Breitbart News.Update ó Shortly after the publication of this of this article, Twitter indicated via email that the ìSmash Racism DCî tweet is ìviolating our rules against abusive behavior,î but the tweet remains live on the platform.Charlie Nash is a reporter†for†Breitbart Tech. You can follow him†on Twitter†@MrNashington, or†like his page at Facebook.

President Donald Trump said Wednesday that Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee should have forced a vote to confirm Judge Kavanaugh sooner.ìThey could have pushed this through two and a half weeks ago and you would not be talking about it right now, which is frankly what I would have preferred,î Trump admitted.He spoke to reporters after he arrived at the United Nations building in New York City on Wednesday morning.Trump noted that Senate Republicans were going out of their way to offer Kavanaughís accuser Christine Ford a chance to testify.ìI think the Senate, the Republicans could not be nicer than the way theyíre handling this,î he said.Senate Republicans scheduled a confirmation vote on Friday, and have offered Ford and Kavanaugh a chance to testify to the committee on Thursday.Trump signaled his impatience with the process, although he provided some deference to Senate Republicans.ìIím OK with that,î he said. ìI think I would have pushed it forward a lot faster.îHe called Kavanaugh ìoutstandingî and ìan absolute gemî and again criticized Democrats for obstructing the proceedings with last-minute allegations.ìThey laugh at what theyíre getting away with, itís a con game and thatís what they play,î he said.

The legal team for†Christine Blasey Ford, the California psychology professor who recently brought forth an allegation of sexual misconduct against Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, sent lawmakers four†sworn and signed declarations from four people claiming to corroborate their clientís accusation,†despite none of the signees having witnessed the alleged incident.NEW: @NBCNews has obtained sworn and signed declarations from 4 people who corroborate Christine Blasey Fordís claims of sexual assault against Kavanaugh, sent to Senate Cmte. pic.twitter.com/psl62NWZ4Jó Peter Alexander (@PeterAlexander) September 26, 2018Here are the other 2 sworn declarations corroborating Fordís claims against Kavanaugh. pic.twitter.com/jtiQT6W1fió Peter Alexander (@PeterAlexander) September 26, 2018According to USA Today, the Senate Judiciary Committee received declarations from Fordís husband, Russell, along with three friends of the California professor, who alleged the accuser disclosed the alleged incident to them on multiple occasions. None of the statements show Ford made any mention of the incident for at least three decades.ìI was walking my dog and Christine was outside of her house,î†Rebecca White, a neighbor of Fordís, wrote of the conversation they shared in 2017 regarding the alleged incident.†ìI stopped to speak with her, and she told me she had read a recent social media post I had written about my own experience with sexual assault.îìShe then told me that when she was a young teen, she had been sexually assaulted by an older teen,î she added. ìI remember her saying that her assailant was now a federal judge.îAccording to†Adela Gildo-Mazzonís declaration, Ford is said to have detailed the alleged incident while sharing a meal together at a†Mountain View, California restaurant in 2013.ìDuring our meal, Christine was visibly upset, so I asked her what was going on,î Gildo-Mazzon wrote. ìChristine told me she had been having a hard day because she was thinking about an assault she experienced when she was much younger. She said she had been almost raped by someone who was now a federal judge. She told me she had been trapped in a room with two drunken guys, and that she had escaped, ran away and hid.îGildo-Mazzon, whose declaration states she has known Ford for over a decade, considers the professor a ìgood friend.îIn Fordís husbandís declaration, Russell alleges he was first made aware of the alleged incident ìaround the time we got marriedî and learned of further details during a 2012 marital therapy session.ìI remember her saying that her attackerís name was Brett Kavanaugh, that he was a successful lawyer who had grown up in Christineís home town, and that he was well-known in the†Washington D.C.†community,î he wrote.While discussing the sexual assault case of†Stanford University student Brock Turner,†Keith Koegler wrote in his declaration that Ford ìexpressed anger at Mr. Turnerís lenient sentence, stating that she was particularly bothered by it because she was assaulted in high school by a man who was now a federal judge in Washington, D.C.îìChristine did not mention the assault to me again until June 29, 2018, two days after Justice Anthony Kennedy announced his resignation from the Supreme Court of the United States,î†Koegler noted.In an email exchange, Koegler claims Ford alleged the individual who had sexually assaulted her was the frontrunner to replace Kennedy.ìI remember you telling me about him, but I donít remember his name. Do you mind telling me so I can read about him?î†Koegler asked Ford.ìBrett Kavanaugh,î she replied.In a Monday interview with Fox News host†Martha MacCallum, Kavanaugh†denied†the decades-old allegations and asked for a ìfair process where I can defend my integrity.îìIíve never sexually assaulted anyone, in high school or otherwise,î the nominee†told†the host. ìI am not questioning, and have not questioned, that perhaps Dr. Ford, at some point in her life, was sexually assaulted by someone, in some place. But what I know is Iíve never sexually assaulted anyone.î†

Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Democratic Socialist and candidate for the U.S. House of Representatives, said on Monday that being accused of sexual assault could benefit oneís career, rather than end it.ìA sexual assault allegation does not kill a career but accelerates it,î Ocasio-Cortez said at Columbia University where she took part in a panel discussion and was asked to weigh in on the unsubstantiated accusations against Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh.ìI hope that at some point, it keeps them up at night,î Ocasio-Cortez said. ìI really do Ö itís beyond politics.îThe Columbia Spectator†reported on the panel discussion, which was moved from the campus to a nearby church because of the universityís prohibition of partisan events.Ocasio-Cortez argued at the event that the progressive base of the Democrat Party is growing and repeated her call for the elimination of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), the federal agency tasked with protecting public safety in the interior of the United States, including protection from criminal illegal aliens.ìWe need to not be afraid to take strong, moral stances,î said Ocasio-Cortez, who won New Yorkís 14th Congressional District primary against veteran Democrat Joe Crowley. ìWe pinned our campaign on a moral argument Ö and then we won on that moral argument Ö Itís not about testing and seeing whatís viable, itís about making things viable.îThe Spectator reported:A student associated with the Roosevelt Institute asked Ocasio-Cortez about her thoughts on Barnardís investment in the Baupost Group, which holds some $911 million in Puerto Rican debt and has called for austerity measures in the area affected by Hurricane Maria.In response, Ocasio-Cortez advised students that the most effective way to enact change at institutions like Columbia or Barnard is to pressure the individuals who hold decision-making power.Ocasio-Cortez also emphasized the importance of engaging with minority groups that Democrats have neglected in the past, saying that if the party does not support marginalized communities, it cannot expect their vote.ìUnless we consciously communicate that we are changing course, with a renewed commitment to these communities, I donít think we can just expect them to turn out,î Ocasio-Cortez said.The event included voter registration.Follow Penny Starr on Twitter.

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-IA) announced Tuesday the identity of the female ìexperienced sex crimes prosecutorî who will question Judge Brett Kavanaugh and his accuser, Christine Blasey Ford, at Thursdayís hearing: Phoenix, Arizonaís number two prosecutor, Rachel Mitchell.Mitchell was hired onto the Judiciary Committeeís roster of staff attorneys for this hearing, taking leave from her office in Phoenix, where she serves as†Maricopa Countyís Deputy County Attorney and division chief the County Attorneyís Officeís Special Victims Division, which handles sex crimes and domestic violence.Mitchell has served for 25 years as a prosecutor in the nationís fourth largest county, including 12 years at the head of the sex-crimes bureau.Grassleyís majority staff had already announced that, despite the protests of Fordís legal team, who evidently would have preferred the appearance of the all-male Republican senators questioning a lone woman, they would appoint a female attorney with specific experience handling sex abuse issues. Her identity, however, was kept private until Tuesday night.In a statement announcing Mitchell as the previously unnamed prosecutor, Grassley wrote:ìAs I have said, Iím committed to providing a forum to both Dr. Ford and Judge Kavanaugh on Thursday that is safe, comfortable and dignified. The majority members have followed the bipartisan recommendation to hire as staff counsel for the committee an experienced career sex-crimes prosecutor to question the witnesses at Thursdayís hearing. The goal is to de-politicize the process and get to the truth, instead of grandstanding and giving senators an opportunity to launch their presidential campaigns. Iím very appreciative that Rachel Mitchell has stepped forward to serve in this important and serious role. Ms. Mitchell has been recognized in the legal community for her experience and objectivity.Some commentators on the political left immediately criticized the pick, trying to tie Mitchell, who is an unelected civil servant, to the controversially convicted ó and now pardoned ó Maricopa County Sheriff Joe Arpaio.The Maricopa†County Attorneyís Office does not report to the Sheriffís Office. As in most counties nationwide, the Maricopa County Attorney is an independently elected official who runs his office independently, since 2010 Republican Bill Montgomery. Sheriff Arpaio at no time exercised authority over any aspect of the†County Attorneyís Office.The Washington Postís Never Trump blogger Jennifer Rubin, who is regularly identified as a ìconservativeî in media outlets despite distancing herself from the term, insulted Mitchell on Twitter shortly after the announcement, making this mistake:Only this crowd of clueless old white guys wold pick someone from Sheriff Joe's operation. I was saying no self-respecting lawyer would take the job of giving cover to GOP cowards. I was right.ó Jennifer Rubin (@JRubinBlogger) September 26, 2018Former Hillary Clinton adviser Philippe Reines made the same error:11 Fraidy Cat Republican *men* need a ringer to do their dirty work: Rachel Mitchell, 26 years in Arizonaís Maricopa County Attorneyís Office, will interrogate Ford, ask Kavanaugh his favorite color. Maricopa County. Rings a bell.OH, Joe Arpaio was sheriff for 25 of her 26 yrs. https://t.co/dRdz8Y0tFnó Philippe Reines (@PhilippeReines) September 26, 2018Some of the attacks on Mitchellís suitability focused on†controversies over inadequate Sheriffís Office sex-crime investigation under Arpaio last decade. Not only did Mitchell not work at the Sheriffís Office, she, as the†Washington Postís Tuesday report notes was, according to her predecessor Cindi Nannetti, ìone of the prosecutors tasked with finding out why hundreds of sex crimes were unresolved or not adequately investigated by the Maricopa County Sheriffís Office.îNannetti also told the Post that Mitchell was ìone of the finest prosecutors in the country.îDefense attorney Tracey Westerhausen, a self-identified Democrat who represented ìmore than 30î defendants Mitchell prosecuted, told the Post, ìPart of the reason weíre very good friends, she is a very nuanced and wise prosecutor. She doesnít pigeonhole defendants. In my experience, she is a very pointed questioner of adverse witnesses. But she is also very fair.î

President Donald Trump continued defending Brett Kavanaugh, urging Americans on Tuesday night to pray for his nominee to the Supreme Court.ìPray for Brett Kavanaugh and his family!î Trump wrote on Twitter, denouncing Democrats for trying to destroy Kavanaugh.He again described Kavanaughís accusers as part of a Democrat plot and a ìcon gameî to destroy his nominee to the Supreme Court.ìThe Democrats are playing a high level CON GAME in their vicious effort to destroy a fine person,î he wrote. ìIt is called the politics of destruction. Behind the scene the Dems are laughing.îSince Christine Blasey Ford first accused Kavanaugh of sexual assault, Trump has remained firmly behind his nominee and his family.ìHis wife is devastated, his children are devastated. I donít mean, ëOh gee, I am a little unhappy.í They are devastated,î he said earlier†on Tuesday. ìAnd it is because of these Democrats.îTrump added that the allegations, which are more than 30 years old, were ìtotally unsubstantiated,î and he warned that it would be a bad precedent for the United States Senate to block Kavanaughís confirmation.ìThis is a high-quality person, and it would be a horrible insult to our country if this doesnít happen,î he said. ìAnd itíll be a horrible, horrible thing for future political people.îTrump has continued to highlight Kavanaughís qualifications for the Supreme Court, touting his great legal mind and character.ìThey know itís a con game. They know heís high quality,î he said about the Democrats. ìAnd they wink at each other. Theyíre winking. They know itís a con game.îThe Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to hear testimony from Ford about her allegations on Thursday ó although it is unclear if she will testify.A Senate vote to confirm Kavanaugh is scheduled for Friday:The Democrats are playing a high level CON GAME in their vicious effort to destroy a fine person. It is called the politics of destruction. Behind the scene the Dems are laughing. Pray for Brett Kavanaugh and his family!ó Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) September 26, 2018

Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett Kavanaughís calendar from the summer of 1982 has been released after being submitted to the Senate Judiciary Committee ó and it reveals an active summer, though the future judge was grounded three weekends in a row.Kavanaugh submitted the calendar this week as evidence that he was not at a party of the kind referred to by Christine Blasey Ford in her accusations that he groped her drunkenly in the presence of others (all of whom have contradicted her claims).Judge Kavanaughís 1982 calendar, submitted to Senate Judiciary Committee pic.twitter.com/VxzMQvgxNEó Jake Tapper (@jaketapper) September 26, 2018The calendar indicates that Kavanaugh ó then in high school ó enjoyed sporting events, trips to the beach, and weightlifting. He was also grounded three weekends in a row in May 1982, for unexplained reasons, though he appears to have been permitted a furlough to attend his prom.Senate Judiciary Committee chair Chuck Grassley (R-IA) has insisted that the hearing featuring Kavanaugh and Ford will take place on Thursday as scheduled, though it is not entirely certain that Ford will testify.On Wednesday morning, Deborah Ramirez, who accused Kavanaugh of exposing himself at a party at Yale ó a story that has also been contradicted by all of the supposed witnesses ó indicated that she, too would be willing to testify, though she had not returned previous requests from the committee for a statement.President Donald Trump has defended his nominee, who has been adamant in his denials and declared earlier this week that he would not give up in the face of accusations he described as false.Joel B. Deborah Ramirez, the second women to level sexual misconduct allegations against Brett Kavanaugh, is refusing to cooperate in any way with the Senate Judiciary Committee.The Washington Examiner reports that Sen. John Kennedy (R-LA), a sitting member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, told staffers Tuesday that Ramirez is refusing to cooperate in any way; she will not testify or even make a statement.Speaking of Ramirezís lawyer, Kennedy said, ìOur counsel repeatedly tried to reach him. They finally did reach him, and he said, ëWe are not issuing a statementí. He said, ëIf you want our statement, read the New Yorker.íîAccording to others present when Kennedy made these remarks, he added that the ìRead the New Yorkerî comment was not a direct quote, just the way he interpreted it.Any testimony given to the Committee, including a statement, would be considered under oath, which carries with it the risk of perjury and imprisonment. So far, everyone appears to agree that Ramirez has not issued a statement, nor has her attorney.The only statement she has made is to the New Yorker, which does not carry any penalty for perjury.For his part, according to the far-left Washington Post, Kavanaugh did speak to the Judiciary Committee on Tuesday and once again denied the Ramirez allegations. During this particular call, Kavanaugh is considered to be under oath and if he is lying would face disgrace, disbarment, and jail time.In a bombshell story co-authored by Ronan Farrow and published in the New Yorker Sunday, Ramirez alleged that during a drunken 1983 party in a Yale dorm room, when both she and the Supreme Court nominee were freshman, Kavanaugh aggressively flashed her.Ramirezís story quickly unraveled, though, and did so on the pages of the New Yorker.For starters, Farrowís in-depth reporting detailed Ramirezís memory problems. In part because she was so intoxicated on the night in question, for 35 years she could not remember who flashed her. It was only when Senate Democrats threatened to tell their version of the story and after she spent six days probing her memory with her attorney (a Democrat politician) that Ramirez agreed to name Kavanaugh.Memory issues are just the beginning of the problems with the Ramirez allegation. Every single person she named as a witness has either said the flashing incident never happened or they did not recall it happening.In other words, as is the case with Kavanaughís first accuser, Christine Blasey Ford, all the named witnesses either say this never happened or they cannot remember it happening.As of now, whether or not Ford will testify under oath is also up in the air. After a week of delays and accommodations, Ford agreed to testify this Thursday. Sen. Diane Feinstein (D-CA), however, said on Tuesday that ìI have no way of knowingî if she will show up.Michael Avenatti, the attorney for porn star Stormy Daniels made famous by CNN, promised on Sunday that he had a third accuser who would come forward within 48 hours against Kavanaugh. On Tuesday, however, Avenatti not only appeared to walk back that promise, he also locked his Twitter account from public view.†Follow John Nolte on Twitter @NolteNC. Follow his Facebook Page here.

The 30-plus hours of confirmation hearings for Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh concluded more than two weeks ago, the high courtís next session begins on October 1, and a majority of Americans believe the time for the Senate to vote is now.Rasmussen Reports poll results released on Tuesday show that 56 percent of likely American voters surveyed by telephone and online agree with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnellís (R-KY) decision to schedule a vote as soon as possible on Kavanaughís nomination.Only 20 percent disagree and 23 percent are undecided, the poll reveals.The vote delay came after Christine Blasey Ford came forward to allege Kavanaugh had groped her at a high school party. Obstruct. Resist.îìTheyíre going to do whatever they could to stop this qualified, experienced and mainstream nominee,î McConnell saidìDemocrats have signaled for months theyíd put on whatever performance the far-left special interest demanded and throw all the mud they could manufacture,î McConnell said. ìBut even by far-left†standards, this shameful, shameful smear campaign has hit a new low.îMcConnell concluded: ìI want to make it perfectly clear, Mr. President. WASHINGTON, DC ñ The Senate Judiciary Committee has scheduled a meeting on September 28, to vote on whether to recommend Judge Brett Kavanaugh to the full Senate for confirmation to the Supreme Court.The committee is currently scheduled to hear testimony under oath from Kavanaugh and his accuser, Christine Blasey Ford, on Thursday. Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-IA) has hired a veteran prosecutor who specializes in sex crime cases to lead the questioning of both witnesses.While it appears certain that Kavanaugh will be there to testify, there are growing doubts ñ including from Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-CA), who initiated the whole affair ñ as to whether Ford will show up at all. (Ford was invited to testify, but is not under subpoena, and therefore has no legal obligation to appear and be placed under oath.)The Judiciary Committeeís rules require three daysí advance notice of any business meeting, so Grassley has issued that notice today if a majority of the committee is prepared to vote after Thursdayís hearing.Once the committee votes on the nomination, it goes to the majority leader ñ Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-KY) who controls the Senate floor schedule for debates and votes. It is certain that McConnell will need to file a cloture motion to bring debate over President Trumpís second Supreme Court pick to a close and proceed to a vote.McConnell has already told senators to expect to stay in Washington on Saturday and even Sunday to move forward on the Kavanaugh nomination.The Supreme Court begins its annual term next Monday, October 1, at 10:00 a.m.Ken Klukowski is senior legal editor for Breitbart News. Follow him on Twitter @kenklukowski.

Vulnerable Senate Democrats told reporters this week they continue to keep an open mind regarding their support for President Donald Trumpís Supreme Court nominee, Judge Brett Kavanaugh.Several Senate Democrats up for re-election this year have remained open to supporting Judge Kavanaugh for the Supreme Court despite the sexual assault allegations brought against the presidentís nominee.Sens. Joe Manchin (D-WV), Joe Donnelly (D-IN), and Heidi Heitkamp (D-ND) face three of the most competitive races this cycle and have continued to watch the accusations against Kavanaugh unfold before they give a decision regarding their support.Manchin told reporters on Monday, ìI want everybody to be able to tell their side of the story if itís validated, and I want him to have a chance to clear his name.îìI just want to hear all the facts, hear what everybody has to say,î†Sen. Donnelly said. He contended that he is not facing pressure to vote to confirm the nominee, stating, ìNo. Iíll just do whatís right, no matter what.îHeitkamp told reporters on Monday that the allegations need to be ìlooked into,î but he declined to elaborate. Rep. Kevin Cramer, Heitkampís Republican challenger, leads the North Dakota Democrat by four points according to a poll released this month.Sen. Jon Tester (D-MT), who faces an increasingly tight race against Montana state auditor Matt Rosendale, still has policy questions for Kavanaugh.ìLook, weíre paying close attention to the allegations. Iíve got other issues, too, that I want to talk to him if we can ever get an in-person [meeting] with him,î Tester said, citing privacy, abortion, and campaign finance. ìWeíve got a long list. And these allegations will also be a part of it.îA survey last week found that Rosendale and Tester are in a virtual tie at 44 percent each.While Manchin, Heitkamp, and Donnelly face increasing pressure to back Kavanaugh for the Supreme Court, they will likely not signal if they will support him until after he receives a 50-vote majority for Senate confirmation. The 50-vote majority largely rests upon Sens. Lisa Murkowski (R-AK) and Susan Collinsí (R-ME) supporting Kavanaugh for the Supreme Court, but they will wait on deciding until they hear California psychology Professor Christine Blasey Fordís testimony about the sexual assault allegations against Kavanaugh.If Collins and Murkowski back Kavanaugh for the Supreme Court, Manchin, Heitkamp, and Donnelly will face continued pressure to vote to confirm him.In contrast to the three Senate Democrats, Sen. Claire McCaskill (D-MO) announced last week she will vote against Kavanaugh, saying the accusation against him was ìtroublingî but did not factor into her decision against the nominee.McCaskill is considered one of the most vulnerable Senate Democrats. A September poll found that Missouri State Attorney General Josh Hawley is now tied with her for the Missouri Senate race.McCaskill said that Kavanaugh ìhas revealed his bias against limits on campaign donations which places him completely out of the mainstream of this nation.î

You have no idea. We donít know the facts. There are people on the other side that are saying heís a liar, heís making up his side of the story. Lawyers for Judge Brett Kavanaughís accuser, Christine Blasey Ford, sent another email to Senate Judiciary Committee staffers Monday night, indicating their displeasure with preparations for their clientís Thursday testimony.Among the issues raised in the email by new addition to the Ford legal team Michael Bromwich (pictured) include the announcement of a female ìexperienced sex crimes prosecutorî as outside counsel. Fordís lawyers have been objecting to Republicansí ability to use anyone by the all-male roster of GOP senators on the Judiciary Committee since their opening salvos last week.ìIn our view, the hiring of an unnamed ëexperienced sex crimes prosecutor,í as [committee staffer Mike] Davis described in his email, is contrary to the Majorityís repeated emphasis on the need for the Senate and this Committeeís members to fulfill their constitutional obligations,î Bromwich writes. ìThis is not a criminal trial for which the involvement of an experienced sex crimes prosecutor would be appropriate.îThe email also includes a new set of demands including a meeting with the as-of-yet unnamed prosecutor Tuesday as well as an explanation of her role and her resume. ìMr. Davis still has not responded to a number of†outstanding questions about the hearing, including an explanation of the role of the ìexperienced sex crimes prosecutorî in the Committee format,î Bromwich writes. ìPlease identify this person and ask your staff to send us her resume immediately. We respectfully request to meet with her tomorrow.îPrevious demands from Fordís legal team have included that Ford testify only after Kavanaugh has, denying him the ability to defend himself from her still-nebulous accusations.Given the repeated postponement on Fordís behalf of the hearing on Fordís allegation that a 17-year-old Kavanaugh groped her at a high school party 36 years ago, this latest salvo of objections had some commentators wondering if the hearing is again in jeopardy. As NBC Newsís Frank Thorp, who first reported the email in a tweet, expressed his doubts:In new letter from Dr Fordís Attorney to the Judiciary Committee, they again object to having outside counsel ask the questions for republicans at Thursdayís hearing, and ask for the name and resume of who that person will be.This does not appear to be a done deal. pic.twitter.com/MwggIeBGbsó Frank Thorp V (@frankthorp) September 25, 2018Whether these new objections prove fatal to Thursdayís eagerly await hearing or not, it is scheduled for a smaller room in the Dirksen Senate Office Building, rather than the main Senate Judiciary Committee room on Fordís request, according to Fox Newsís Chad Pegram.† The witness list has also been published. It contains just two names: Christine Blasey Ford and Brett Kavanaugh.

WASHINGTON, DC ó Judge Brett Kavanaugh spoke publicly on Monday for the first time since being accused of sexual misconduct, telling Fox News Channelís Martha McCallum that the accusations against him are categorically false, that he looks forward to clearing his name before the Senate, and that all he asks for is a fair process.Kavanaugh appeared with his wife Ashley on Fox Newsís†The Story, answering questions from McCallum ahead of his Thursday testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee. At issue are allegations from Christine Blasey Ford, who said Kavanaugh groped her at a party when he was 17 years old, and from Deborah Ramirez, who said he exposed himself at a drunken dormitory party when they were freshmen together at Yale.Both womenís accounts are currently unraveling, with the five people Ford said were at the party in question all denying her account, and with more than a dozen people contacted regarding Ramirezís accusations likewise denying the second account.ìAll Iím asking for is fairness and that I be heard in this process,î Kavanaugh said early in the interview, a theme he would repeat several times to emphasize what he was looking for during this unexpected add-on part of his Senate confirmation process to the U.S. Supreme Court.Responding directly to the accusations against him, Kavanaugh was emphatic. ìIíve never sexually assaulted anyone ó not in high school, not ever,î he told McCallum.He noted that within 24 hours of being accused, 65 women who knew him as a student signed a letter affirming that he always conducted himself with grace and dignity and unfailingly acted as a gentleman around women.Nor did he think there was much opportunity to have interacted with Ford. ìWe did not travel in the same social circles,î the 53-year-old told McCallum.ìI was never at any such party,î Kavanaugh said of the event Ford described. ìThe other people who were alleged to be present say that they do not remember any such party.îThe judge also cited the fact that the other teenage young woman Ford named in her story, Leland Keyser, has publicly denied Fordís description of the party. ìShe doesnít know me and never remembers being at a party with me any time in her life,î he recounted from Keyserís response.Brettís wife Ashley was at his side during the interview†and explained why she did not believe these allegations.ìHeís decent. Heís kind,î Ashley asserted. ìHeís good. I know his heart.îRegarding the second accuser, Ramirez, Kavanaugh cut to the chase as to why many commentators think that Ramirez is crashing and burning only 24 hours after going public.ìThe New York Times†just reported that just last week, the person making the accusation was calling other classmates saying she was not sure that I had done this,î he explained. The Times chose not to run the story after they contacted more than a dozen people, none of whom could corroborate Ramirezís account that Kavanaugh exposed himself to her at a Yale party in which she admitted that she was severely drunk.The interview was uncomfortably candid when Kavanaugh explained that these playboy accusations did not fit the reality that, as a young man, he was something of a ìnerd,î a top student focused on academics rather than a ladyís man. ìI did not have sexual intercourse or anything close to sexual intercourse in high school or for many years thereafter,î he told McCallum.ìSo youíre saying, through all these years in question, you were a virgin?î McCallum asked, referencing the fact that it is uncomfortably unfortunate to have to discuss such intimate personal details in light of the accusations.ìThatís correct,î the judge confirmed.They elevated the discussion by focusing on the path forward by talking about what the nominee was looking for going forward.ìI want a fair process where I can defend my integrity,î Kavanaugh asserted.ìIím not going to let false accusations drive me out of this process,î he responded when McCallum explored whether he was willing to withdraw from the process. ìI have faith in God and faith in the fairness of the American people. America is about fairness, and hearing from both sides.îìI was first interviewed last Monday, the day after the allegation appeared,î the judge explained, ìunder penalty of felony, and I denied this categorically and unequivocally, and I said twice during that ó I want a hearing tomorrow.îìI want to clear my name as quickly as possible,î he declared.He admitted that he has his flaws but insisted that he is innocent of these accusations.ìI think everyone is judged on their whole life. Iím a good person,î Kavanaugh opined. ìIíve led a good life. Iíve tried to do a lot of good for a lot of people. I am not perfect. I know that. None of us is perfect. But Iíve never done anything like this.îAshley addressed the human toll of this ordeal. ìItís very difficult to have these conversations with your children,î she said.She told their two young daughters, ìJust remember, you know your dad.îReferencing the political reality of presidents who sometimes distance themselves from nominees who become problematic, McCallum asked Kavanaugh if President Donald Trump is going to stick with him.ìI know heís going to stand by me,î Kavanaugh responded, saying that the president had recently contacted him to assure him of his support. ìHe called me this afternoon.îThe Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to hear from Kavanaugh this Thursday.Ken Klukowski is senior legal editor for Breitbart News. Follow him on Twitter @kenklukowski.

The following day, Fordís legal team convinced members of Grassleyís staff to allow their client to appear before the panel on Thursday. The tentative agreement came after lawyers for Ford accused the Republicans of being†ìfundamentally inconsistent with the committeeís promise of a fair, impartial investigation into her allegations.î Earlier this month, Ford publically detailed her allegation to the Washington Post, accusing Kavanaugh, then in high school, of forcing her into a room and groping her at a house party around 1982.The Post also reports that in the wake of allegations against Kavanaugh,†President Trump believes, ìRepublicans are too easily manipulated by Democrats,î a view widely shared by his supporters, who see the likes of Sens.†Mazie Hirono (D-HI) and†Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY) as bad faith actors attempting to derail the Supreme Court nomineeís confirmation for purely political purposes. Documents obtained Monday by Breitbart News indicate Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-IA) has enlisted an†ìexperienced sex-crimes prosecutorî to handle questioning at Thursdayís hearing on the 36-year-old sexual misconduct allegations against Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett Kavanaugh.The prosecutor has not yet been publicly identified but the documents indicate she is a woman.The use of an outside counsel, a lawyer not normally attached to the Senate, for questioning in investigative hearings is not unusual. In the case of Christine Blasey Fordís accusation that a drunken 17-year-old Kavanaugh pulled her into a bedroom at a high school party with another teenager and groped her, however, the use of one has proved a major bone of contention.Fordís legal team, led by Democratic activist Deborah Katz and now joined by Bill Clinton era Justice Department Inspector General Michael Bromwich, has repeatedly demanded the Senate Judiciary Committee agree not to use a presumably female outside counsel in this hearing. Republican staffers on the committee have reportedly expressed concerns about the ìopticsî of the panel of 11 GOP senators, all men, conducting the questioning of a sexual assault accuser on their own.Evidently concerned with preserving those favorable optics, Fordís legal team, while urging continual delays and postponements for nearly a week, insisted on the Republican senators asking all questions of Ford on their own as a condition for Fordís testimony. Other demands included allowing Ford, the accuser, to testify after Kavanaugh, the accused ñ the exact opposite of centuries of Anglo-American legal tradition. Grassleyís staff called that request ìan affront to fundamental notions of due processî in their response Friday.As to Katzís demand to refrain from enlisting a female lawyer to question Ford, Grassleyís staff also stood their ground, writing, ìThere is no rule of the Senate or the Committee that precludes staff attorneys from asking witnesses questions. We reserve the option to have female staff attorneys, who are sensitive to the particulars of Dr. Fordís allegations and are experienced investigators, question both witnesses.îFordís legal team has been informed of the decision to use†an ìexperienced sex-crimes prosecutorî at Thursdayís hearing, now scheduled for 10:00 a.m.

The New Yorkerís Ronan Farrow and his co-author Jane Mayer are under fire for publishing a second allegation of sexual misconduct against Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh. When you look at how thin the story is, that criticism might be valid.But Farrow (pictured, top right) and Mayer (pictured, top left) deserve credit for writing the full story ó a story that not only appears to debunk Deborah Ramirezís allegation but exposes how the institutional left is aggressively working behind the scenes to destroy Kavanaugh with spurious accusations.After 35 years of not being sure it was him, Ramirez now alleges that during a drunken dorm party during her and Kavanaughís freshman year at Yale in 1983, he exposed himself to her in such an aggressive way she ended up accidentally touching his genitals.Obviously, this is a sensational allegation, and the timing is more than a little suspicious. The story appeared on Sunday night just as Christine Blasey Fordís allegations against Kavanaugh began to unravel.Just a few hours earlier, the last of Fordís three witnesses, including a lifelong friend, had not only said (under penalty of imprisonment) they do not recall any misconduct on Kavanaughís part, they do not even recall attending the 1982 house party where the misconduct supposedly occurred.If anything, though, Ramirezís story is even less credible.Like Ford, neither of Ramirezís witnesses recall the party or the alleged incident, nor does her best friend. Whatís more, until Ramirez spent six days with her Democrat lawyer, she was unable to identify Kavanaugh as the man who exposed himself.Because of Ramirezís memory problems (she was also quite drunk at the alleged party) and her supposed witnesses stating none of this ever happened, some argue the New Yorker was irresponsible to publish. In fact, the New York Times found the story so lacking in credibility, the paper chose not to publish.But were it not for the New Yorker, we would not have learned how Democrats are willing to manipulate events behind the scenes in their ongoing effort to destroy Kavanaugh with unsubstantiated allegations from more than 30 years ago.The New Yorker informs us:In her initial conversations with†The New Yorker, she was reluctant to characterize Kavanaughís role in the alleged incident with certainty. After six days of carefully assessing her memories and consulting with her attorney, Ramirez said that she felt confident enough of her recollections to say that she remembers Kavanaugh†had exposed himself at a drunken dormitory party, thrust his penis in her face, and caused her to touch it without her consent as she pushed him away.In other words, a full 35 years after the incident occurred, Ramirez (who the New Yorker describes as an activist Democrat) could not put the finger on Kavanaugh as the alleged flasher.Moreover, we learn ìRamirez acknowledged that there are significant gaps in her memories of the eveningî and that at the party she ìbecame inebriatedî and ìwas on the floor, foggy and slurring her words.îNevertheless, after all this time, over the past few days, she became sure it was Kavanaugh thanks to ìcarefully assessing her memories and consulting with her attorney.îThanks to the New Yorkerís in-depth reporting, however, we know exactly who the attorney is who helped Ramirez recall her memory ó ìStanley Garnett, a former Democratic district attorneyî from Boulder,†Colorado.And then there is the role Senate Democrats playedÖAppearing on Good Morning America Monday, Farrow disclosed that Senate Democrats instigated this by reaching out to Ramirez, who had no intention of reporting the incident because she was not sure it was Kavanaugh. One of the primary reasons she came forward, according to Farrow, is that she feared Democrats would tell the story for her.ìShe felt it was important that she tell her story before others did without her consent because so many people on [Capitol] Hill were looking at this,î Farrow said.Farrow also admitted there are no eyewitnesses of this incident.In fact, as the New Yorker reports, the two people named by Ramirez as witnesses state the incident never happened:One of the male classmates who Ramirez said egged on Kavanaugh denied any memory of the party. ìI donít think Brett would flash himself to Debbie, or anyone, for that matter,î he said. Asked why he thought Ramirez was making the allegation, he responded, ìI have no idea.î The other male classmate who Ramirez said was involved in the incident commented, ìI have zero recollection.îAdditionally, Ramirezís own best friend at the time says she knew nothing about this:ìThis is a woman I was best friends with. We shared intimate details of our lives. And I was never told this story by her, or by anyone else. It never came up. I didnít see it; I never heard of it happening.î She said she hadnít spoken with Ramirez for about ten years, but that the two women had been close all through college, and Kavanaugh had remained part of what she called their ìlarger social circle.î In an initial†conversation with†The New Yorker, she suggested that Ramirez may have been politically motivated. Later, she said that she did not know if this was the case.Then there are the three classmates who also back Kavanaughís claim:Dino Ewing, Louisa Garry, and Dan Murphy, disputed Ramirezís account of events: ìWe were the people closest to Brett Kavanaugh during his first year at Yale. He was a roommate to some of us, and we spent a great deal of time with him, including in the dorm where this incident allegedly took place. Some of us were also friends with Debbie Ramirez during and after her time at Yale. We can say with confidence that if the incident Debbie alleges ever occurred, we would have seen or heard about itóand we did not. The behavior she describes would be completely out of character for Brett. The two women making sexual misconduct allegations against Brett Kavanaugh claim to have witnesses, but so far, all of their witnesses back Kavanaughís claim that nothing happened.It might be difficult to remember this as Democrats and the media throw around phrases like ìsecond accuserî and ìattempted sexual assaultî and ìexposing himselfî against the Supreme Court nominee.
