She named three people who were at the party: PJ Smyth, Mark Judge, and Leland Ingham Keyser.By submitting their respective statements to the Senate Judiciary Committee, all three witnesses did so under penalty of imprisonment, and all three have zero recollection of the house party in question.The one witness whom Ford said was in the room when the alleged misconduct took place (Mark Judge) denies it happened. Moreover, another witness, a lifelong friend of Fordís, not only cannot remember the house party, she says she has never met Kavanaugh.PJ Smyth:I understand that I have been identified by Dr. Christine Blasey Ford as the person she remembers as ìPJî who supposedly was present at the party she described in her statements to the Washington Post. I am issuing this statement today to make it clear to all involved that I have no knowledge of the party in question; nor do I have any knowledge of the allegations of improper conduct she has leveled against Brett Kavanaugh. Personally speaking, I have known Brett Kavanaugh since high school and I know him to be a person of great integrity, a great friend, and I have never witnessed any improper conduct by Brett Kavanaugh towards women.Mark Judge†said, ìI have no memory of the alleged incident. Brett Kavanaugh and I were friends in high school but I do not recall the party described in Dr. Fordís letter. More to the point, I never saw Brett act in the manner Ford describes.îLeland Ingham Keyser stated, ìSimply put, Ms. Keyser does not know Mr. Kavanaugh and she has no recollection of ever being at a party or gathering where he was present, with, or without, Dr. Ford.îThe above is an email that Keyserís attorney, Howard Walsh, sent to the Judiciary Committee.Furthermore, Keyser is the ex-wife of Democrat operative Bob Beckel and currently produces his podcast. According to public reports, she has only ever donated to Democrats. The far-left CNN reports that Keyser and Ford are ìlifelong friends.îFor his own part, and under penalty of imprisonment, Kavanaugh not only denies any allegation that he acted improperly with Ford (or anyone), he denies being at this party ó a party no one other than Ford remembers.A second accuser came forward Sunday night in a piece the New Yorkerís Ronan Farrow co-authored. Deborah Ramirez alleges that an 18-year-old Kavanaugh exposed himself to her during a drunken 1983 dorm party at Yale.By any standard, this story is a mess, including Ramirezís own ìrecollection.î She admits she was drinking heavily at the party and that there are ìsignificant gaps in her memory of the evening.îWhen the New Yorker†first contacted Ramirez, she said she could not say if it was Kavanaugh who exposed himself. But after ìsix days of carefully assessing her memories and consulting with her attorney, Ramirez said that she felt confident enough of her recollections to say that she remembers Kavanaugh had exposed himself at a drunken dormitory party.îThe New Yorker added that it ìhas not confirmed with other eyewitnesses that Kavanaugh was present at the party.îIn other words, like the Ford allegation, the New Yorker is not only unable to verify that Kavanaugh exposed himself, none of the witnesses can confirm Kavanaugh even attended the party.The only so-called corroboration comes from an anonymous source who claims to have heard the story second hand. He says, ìAnother student told him about the incident either on the night of the party or in the next day or two.î Another former classmate remembers hearing something about this but has no recollection of who was involved.But the witnesses Ramirez actually named say nothing happened:Witness 1:One of the male classmates who Ramirez said egged on Kavanaugh denied any memory of the party. ìI donít think Brett would flash himself to Debbie, or anyone, for that matter,î he said. Asked why he thought Ramirez was making the allegation, he responded, ìI have no idea.îWitness 2: stated, ìThe other male classmate who Ramirez said was involved in the incident commented, ëI have zero recollection.íîClassmates 3, 4, and 5:In a statement, two of those male classmates who Ramirez alleged were involved in the incident, the wife of a third male student she said was involved, and three other classmates, Dino Ewing, Louisa Garry, and Dan Murphy, disputed Ramirezís account of events: ìWe were the people closest to Brett Kavanaugh during his first year at Yale. He was a roommate to some of us, and we spent a great deal of time with him, including in the dorm where this incident allegedly took place. Some of us were also friends with Debbie Ramirez during and after her time at Yale. We can say with confidence that if the incident Debbie alleges ever occurred, we would have seen or heard about itóand we did not. The behavior she describes would be completely out of character for Brett. In addition, some of us knew Debbie long after Yale, and she never described this incident until Brettís Supreme Court nomination was pending. Editors from the New Yorker contacted some of us because we are the people who would know the truth, and we told them that we never saw or heard about this.îRamirezís best friend at Yale:ìThis is a woman I was best friends with. We shared intimate details of our lives. And I was never told this story by her, or by anyone else. It never came up. I didnít see it; I never heard of it happening.î She said she hadnít spoken with Ramirez for about ten years, but that the two women had been close all through college, and Kavanaugh had remained part of what she called their ìlarger social circle.îIn a statement released Sunday, Kavanaugh called the Ramirez allegation a ìsmear, plain and simple,î and added (accurately), ìPeople who knew me then know that this did not happen, and have said so.îOnce you separate the media sensationalism and the political posturing from the actual facts, what we have here is a remarkable situation where every witness named by Kavanaughís accusers Ö sides with Kavanaugh.†Follow John Nolte on Twitter @NolteNC. The New Yorker reported a new accusation Sunday evening against Judge Brett Kavanaugh: that as a college freshman at Yale University, a drunken Kavanaugh ìexposed himself at a drunken dormitory party,î and that when she tried to push him away in her drunken condition she accidently touched his penis.The article, by Ronan Farrow and Jane Mayer, comes hours after Christine Balsey Ford agreed to testify Thursday about an allegation that Kavanaugh groped her in high school.Kavanaugh denies the allegation, in a statement reported by the†New Yorker: ìThis alleged event from 35 years ago did not happen. The people who knew me then know that this did not happen, and have said so. This is a smear, plain and simple. I look forward to testifying on Thursday about the truth, and defending my good nameñand the reputation for character and integrity I have spent a lifetime buildingñagainst these last-minute allegations.î The White House called it ìthe latest in a coordinated smear campaign by the Democrats designed to tear down a good man.îFarrow and Mayer admit that†Deborah Ramirez, the woman making the accusation, acknowledges being drunk at the party where she alleges the incident occurred, and that ìher memories contained gaps.î They also note: ìThe New Yorker has not confirmed with other eyewitnesses that Kavanaugh was present at the party.†The magazine contacted several dozen classmates of Ramirez and Kavanaugh regarding the incident. Many did not respond to interview requests; others declined to comment, or said they did not attend or remember the party.îOne classmate of Ramirez, who declined to be named, said that he was told later about the party and that he remembered being told that Kavanaugh had behaved as described. Others had apparently also heard similar stories but not the names of those involved.However, a woman who described herself as Ramirezís best friend at the time told the New Yorker that she never heard about the story: ìI was never told this story by her, or by anyone else. It never came up. I didnít see it; I never heard of it happening.îFarrow and Mayer also explore other allegations about wild behavior involving ìKavanaugh and his social scene,î without connecting him to further allegations.They note that Kavanaugh had previously told the Senate Judiciary Committee, in response to a standard question from Sen. Mazie Hirono (D-HI) that he had never committed any sexual misconduct as a ìlegal adult.î Kavanaugh would have been 18 at the time of the alleged incident.Read the full story here.Joel B. Democrats are determined to sink Judge Brett Kavanaughís nomination to the U.S. Supreme Court even if Christine Blasey Fordís original accusation unravels ó as it is beginning to do, with all four named witnesses thus far contradicting her story.But the left is not above dirty tricks ó such as failing to mention the accusation against Kavanaugh until after the confirmation hearings ó and there are several more Democrats could pull that might have the potential to block Kavanaugh regardless.1. Create additional accusations. Even assuming that Dr. Fordís story is true, one of the problems that Democrats have faced is that Kavanaugh has shown no similar pattern of behavior. But if one or more new accusers emerged, that could create new suspicions that would at least delay his confirmation. The accusations would not need to be true; they would just need to cast the judge in a negative light. (Sunday nightís ìdildoî story, apparently in the works from the New Yorker,†is a perfect example.)2. Instigate a local prosecution. If state or county prosectors were to announce that they were investigating Kavanaugh for attempted rape, which has no statue of limitations in Maryland, that could end his confirmation. If that sounds far-fetched, State Sen. Cheryl Kagan (D-Montgomery) has already tried it, urging Gov. Larry Hogan to order an investigation by state police. He refused, but prosectors in the office of the Montgomery County stateís attorney ó a Democrat ó are noncommittal.3. Block the hearing.†Fordís claims could look less credible by Thursday. Kavanaugh reportedly produced calendars from 1982 on Sunday showing he was out of town for much of the period in question. If so, Democrats might not want Ford to testify ó but might want to delay a committee vote. They†praised the protesters who interrupted Kavanaughís confirmation hearing earlier this month; they could arrange massive protests during or before the hearing to disrupt it and delay the process.4. Organize a Bar protest. The left-leaning American Bar Association (ABA) gave Kavanaugh a unanimous ìwell-qualifiedî rating before his confirmation hearings. But Democrats could organize left-leaning lawyers to pressure the ABA to revise that conclusion, or to issue a statement of protest. Alternatively, they could organize a ìlawyersí protestî of their own, stating that they will refuse to argue cases before the Supreme Court so long as Kavanaugh is seated without a full FBI investigation.5. Character assassination.†If Fordís story falls apart, the campaign against Kavanaugh will go down as one of the worst smear campaigns in American history. But Democrats have time to make it even worse. They can ratchet up the pressure on the judge and his family to the point where he concludes it is simply not worth the effort. Already, the†Washington Post is reporting that Kavanaugh refused to answer some personal questions in mock hearings ó hinting, perhaps, at worse to come.Joel B. Gary Bauer, conservative activist and former president of the Family Research Council (FRC), said on Friday that the politicization of the Supreme Court nominee confirmation process has been going on for decades but is reaching new levels today as the United States Senate considers Brett Kavanaugh for a seat on the high court.ìThis is a travesty,î Bauer said at the 2018 Values Voter Summit in Washington, D.C.† ìI cannot imagine what it has felt like for Judge Kavanaugh to be in that hearing room.îìItís almost like political waterboarding ó thatís what our political process has become,î Bauer said.Bauer, who has been in Washington for more than three decades and has witnessed the confirmation process for judges in four Republican administrations, provided a history lesson, beginning with President Ronald Reaganís nomination of Robert Bork, who was voted down because he was an atheist by a Senate that is tasked with preserving and protecting Americansí religious liberty.President George H.W. Bush nominated David Souter, who turned out not to be a conservative, but then Bush redeemed himself, Bauer said, when he nominated Clarence Thomas, in 1991, to replace Thurgood Marshall.Clarence Thomasís confirmation, like Kavanaughís, was thrown into chaos when, near the end of the process Anita Hill, ó a woman who had worked with Thomas at the United States Department of Education and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) ó accused him of sexual harassment in a report leaked to the media.Thomas categorically denied he had ever spoken inappropriately to Hill or shared pornographic materials with her as she claimed.Bauer said he and other Thomas supporters formed the Citizens Committee to Confirm Clarence Thomas to fight against the Democrats and pro-abortion activists who opposed him, just like Kavanaughís opposition.But, Bauer said, rather than the loud and rude protesters at Kavanaughís recent hearing, supporters showed up to cheer Thomas on as he faced the Senate Democratsí scathing interrogation.ìFor Clarence Thomas ó with that being the last thing he saw ó walked into the hearing room, sat down at that chair and confronted those senators,î Bauer said.ìImagine this young man that had grown up in poverty, raised by a single mother, had overcome all kinds of problems to get to the level where he was,î Bauer said of Thomas. ìBut he had made one mistake in his life. He was a black American willing to defend conservative principles. And that is why they needed to stop him.îBauer read from Thomasís now iconic testimony, which came as something new to many of the young people at the summit.ìThis is not an opportunity to talk about difficult problems privately or in a closed environment,î Thomas said. ìThis is a circus.îìItís a national disgrace,î Thomas said. ìAnd from my standpoint as a black American, it is a high tech lynching for uppity blacks who in any way deign to think for themselves, to do for themselves, to have different ideas.îìAnd it is a message that unless you kowtow to an old order this is what will happen to you,î Thomas said. ìYou will be lynched, destroyed, caricatured by a committee of the U.S. Senate rather than hung from a tree.îìThatís what weíre going through now,î Bauer said. ìA circus.îìWhen the history books that matter are written, it will show that because of Clarence Thomasí fifth vote, time and time again, that this country is a better place than it would have been otherwise,î Bauer said.Fast forward to today and Christine Blasey Fordís 11th-hour claim that Kavanaugh groped her at a party 35 years ago when the two were in high school.But even if the similarities between the nominations of Thomas and Kavanaugh are striking, the outcome his opponents seek is more than destroying a manís reputation and ambitions.Thatís clear from what unfolded at Kavanaughís hearings, Bauer said, including the behavior of Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee. He cited Sen. Kamala Harris (D-CA) and Cory Booker (D-NJ) and their pandering to todayís radical left in the Democratic Party.ì[Booker] knows the current grassroots of the progressive Democrat movement in this country is demanding that people like Senator Booker break all the rules to resist the duly elected president and vice president of the United States and to overturn the election results where 63 million Americans voted for [President Donald Trump],î Bauer said.Bauer also chided Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-CA), the ranking member on the committee, who has had Fordís letter since July and did not bring up its existence at Kavanaughís hearings or in her private meeting with him.ìShe sat on that letter hoping, I suspect, that these other tactics they were using would be able to stop judge Kavanaugh,î Bauer said. ìAnd when it failed, then all of a sudden the letter becomes public and we are in the middle of this circus.îBauer said there is no proof yet that what Ford alleges is true, ëbut there is something we can prove, and thatís Kavanaughís character,î which he said is clear not only in his professional record but from the dozens and dozens of people who have spoken out on his behalf.Moreover, at the end of the day, Bauer said he believes another stellar conservative will be seated on the high court.ìAnd my friends in a few weeks, when Judge Kavanaugh is sworn in as the next Supreme Court justice, we will not just be celebrating that day, we will be celebrating for the next 30 years,î Bauer said.Follow Penny Starr on Twitter

Michael Bromwich, the Justice Department (DOJ) inspector general for the bulk of President Bill Clintonís administration, announced Saturday he had joined Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett Kavanaughís accuserís legal team under lead attorney Deborah Katz.Bromwich is also representing fired FBI Deputy Director Andy McCabe, who is facing criminal prosecution for allegedly lying to DOJ Office of the Inspector General (OIG) investigators during their probe of leaks to the media during the Clinton email investigation McCabe oversaw. A grand jury has reportedly been impaneled in that case.Bromwich and his business partner Melissa Schwartz confirmed reports he had agreed to help Christine Blasey Ford on Twitter:Iím honored to be joining Debra Katz and Lisa Banks in representing Dr. Ford https://t.co/WdhWj0qmSwó Michael R. Bromwich (@mrbromwich) September 22, 2018Ford accuses Kavanaugh of having drunkenly groped her at a high school party when he was 17.Like Katz, a Democratic donor and left-wing activist, Bromwich has a long history of involvement in cases closely tied to the political ambitions of the Democratic Party. During the Iran-Contra scandal of the 1980s, he served as an Office of Independent Counsel prosecutor. He helped secure convictions of Reagan administration National Security Council staffer Lt. Col. Oliver North. Those convictions were all later reversed on appeal.In 2010, following the Deepwater Horizon disaster, President Barack Obama picked Bromwich to oversee efforts to overhaul offshore drilling regulations. His recommendations quickly came under fire from the energy industry for ìstiflingî production.In 2012, as the Fast and Furious scandal broke, Bromwich served as counsel to Jason Weinstein, a DOJ official he had originally hired in the 1990s who resigned from the department after Inspector General Michael Horowitzís report savaged him over his oversight of the ATFís ìFast and Furiousî gun-walking operation.Bromwich will join Fordís team shortly after Katz sent the Senate Judiciary Committee a letter in which she claims her client ìagreesî to testify. The text of that letter, however, quickly makes clear Katz has come to no agreement, having agreed neither to any of the dates offered by the committee or to any of the terms that were made clear in a letter addressed to Fordís legal team on Friday.As with all previous public communications on the matter, Katz demands further delays, which, at this point, stand the very real possibility of rendering Kavanaughís confirmation before the start of the Supreme Courtís October term impossible.

A new poll from The Huffington Post indicates that only a quarter of women believe that the sexual misconduct allegations against Supreme Court nominee Brett†Kavanaugh are credible.25 percent of women responding say that the allegations against Brett Kavanaugh are credible, while 35 percent say that they havenít heard enough to decide and 18 percent arenít sure, according to a new poll from HuffPost/YouGov.For men, there are less who are undecided: 28 percent say that they find the allegations credible, but 34 percent who say they are not credible. 29 percent of men havenít heard enough and 10 percent arenít sure.The poll was taken between†September 17 ñ 18 and samples 1000 adults in the U.S.In a Washington Post article published Sunday, Christine Blasey Ford accused Kavanaugh of sexually assaulting her when he was 17 years old and ìstumbling drunkî in high school in 1982.According to the Postës report, he allegedly ìgroped her over her clothes, grinding his body against hers and clumsily attempting to pull off her one-piece bathing suit and the clothing she wore over it.îKavanaugh has defended himself from the accusation, saying, ìI have never done anything like what the accuser describesóto her or to anyone.îìBecause this never happened, I had no idea who was making this accusation until she identified herself yesterday,î he stated.Mark Judge, a classmate of Kavanaughís who was named by Ford, said that the allegations were ìabsolutely nuts.îMany Republicans are standing with Kavanaugh. But hereís what I want to tell you: in the very near future, Judge Kavanaugh will be on the United States Supreme Court.îìSo my friends, keep the faith. Donít be rattled by all of this. Hillary Clinton told Stephen Colbert Friday that the FBI needs to investigate the sexual misconduct allegations against Brett Kavanaugh.The two-time presidential loser appeared on the anti-Trump late-night show to publicize the paperback version of her book What Happened. Inevitably, the conversation turned to the 36-year-old allegations against the supreme court nominee.As of now, things are at a standstill. Kavanaughís accuser, Christine Blasey Ford, has missed numerous deadlines to agree to testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee, even as Republicans bend over backward to accommodate her demands ó some of which are being criticized as unreasonable. For example, Ford does not want Kavanaugh to have the chance to rebut her testimony, she does not want to be questioned by lawyers, and she refuses to fly in from California.Many see these as delaying tactics, as an attempt by Ford and her left-wing handlers to stretch out the process until after the election, which could kill Kavanaughís confirmation if Democrats take over the Senate.Another delaying tactic has been this call for an FBI investigation. Although the FBI does not investigate local crimes, Ford, Democrats, and now Hillary Clinton continue to push for the FBI to get involved in an alleged incident that happened in 1982 when Kavanaugh was still a minor ó 17-years-old.Whatís more, Ford says she cannot remember where or when it happened.For his part, Kavanaugh unambiguously denies the allegation and two witnesses back him up. Whatís more, unlike his accuser, Kavanaugh appears eager to testify to his innocence in public and under the penalty of perjury.On Friday, Hillary not only called for the FBI to get involved, she also accused Republicans, who are now in a second week of delay, of rushing things.Republicans are ìtrying to rush this through to the detriment of the American public who deserves to have answers to whatever charges might be presented,î she said.ìSo Iím hoping that at some point there will be an agreement to have an investigation,î she added. ìIt would be very easy for the FBI to go back and finish the background investigation, to investigate these charges.îThe FBI has already completed six background checks on Kavanaugh.ìAnd, you know, maybe find out thereís nothing to them, maybe find out thereís something to them, but at least have that investigation completed. And I think thatís what is a fair request, for due process to be asked for.îColbert also brought up Merrick Garland, who was President Obamaís Supreme Court nominee after the 2016 death of Antonin Scalia.ìDo you think the nomination process in general is irreparably damaged following the Republicans not allowing Merrick Garland to be heard?î Colbert asked.ìWell, itís one of the reasons I think a lot of Americans are just fed up with the political process,î Clinton answered, adding, ìBecause in a democracy, you have to have at least enough trust to be able to work with each other and try to solve difficult problems.îReferring directly to Garland, she said, ìWhen the Republicans refused to give a distinguished judge, appointed by President Obama, even the courtesy of meetings let alone a hearing, that sent such a terrible message.îWhat Clinton left out, though, is that Republicans refused to consider Garland because this Supreme Court opening occurred in the heat of the 2016 presidential election.The precedent for not going through a Supreme Court confirmation process during a presidential election year is nothing new. In fact, Barack Obamaís own vice president backed this precedent in 1992.There was no Supreme Court vacancy in 1992. When he made those remarks (linked above), Biden was getting ahead of that possibility. But had there been a vacancy in 1992, and had the vacancy been held until after the election, it would have been Hillary Clintonís husband, President Bill Clinton, who benefited from the precedent.Lost on no one, though, except the sycophantic Colbert, is the irony of having Hillary Clinton (of all people) seriously discuss the issue of sexual misconduct. For decades Hillary has been seen as her husbandís chief enabler, a man credibly accused of rape, who settled a sexual harassment suit as president, who engaged in a sleazy Oval Office sexual affair with a young subordinateÖThe left, including feminists, and the establishment media, never wanted the FBI to investigate any of this.†Follow John Nolte on Twitter @NolteNC. A†Star-Ledger†columnist has revisited a piece written by New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker, in which he admitted to ìgropingî a female friend at age 15.On Thursday, Paul Mulshine asked, ìGuess who wrote the followingî:New Yearís Eve 1984 I will never forget. I was 15. As the ball dropped, I leaned over to hug a friend and she met me instead with an overwhelming kiss. As we fumbled upon the bed, I remember debating my next ëmoveí as if it were a chess game. With the ìTop Gunî slogan ringing in my head, I slowly reached for her breast. After having my hand pushed away once, I reached my ìmark.îOur groping ended soon and while no ìrelationshipî ensued, a friendship did. You see, the next week in school she told me that she was drunk that night and didnít really know what she was doing.Mulshine had cited a portion of a piece†written in 1992 by ñ as he calls him ñ ìour junior U.S. Senator, Cory ëSpartacusí Booker,î when the senator was a student at Stanford University.The column, titled ìSo Much for Stealing Second,î was apparently written by Booker to highlight his conversion from a 15-year-old who was ìtrotting around the bases and stealing secondî to a ìsensitive manî who came to understand women as victims of menís sexual ìpower plays.îIn his piece, Booker proudly boasted that his transformation was so stark, one college friend even referred to him as a ìman-hater.îIn a second column,†cited by Fox News, in which Booker referred to ìdate rape,î he admitted, ìWith this issue as with so many others, a dash of sincere introspection has revealed to me a dangerous gap ó a gap between my beliefs and my actions.îBookerís writings have drawn criticism, as they have circulated once again, since he is considered to be a potential 2020 presidential contender.ìBut that column puts the senator in an awkward position regarding the allegations against Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh by psychologist Christine Blasey Ford,î Mulshine pointed out as well.Now-Sen. Booker has called for a delay in the vote to confirm Kavanaugh, in light of Fordís accusation of sexual misconduct against the nominee ñ which Kavanaugh denies ñ over 35 years ago.ìIt takes enormous courage to come forward publicly as Ms. Ford has,î Booker said. ìThe Senate owes it to her and every survivor of sexual trauma to listen to her story and gather all of the facts before moving forward with this nomination.îThe New Jersey Democrat also said Fordís accusations against Kavanaugh are ìserious, credible, and deeply troubling,î and called for an FBI investigation into the allegations.ìBut based on that Stanford Daily column, Booker should be giving Kavanaugh the benefit of the doubt as well,î Mulshine asserted. ìThe point of it was that the future senator had ëa wake-up callí and decided ëI will never be the same.íîLeading Anti-Kavanaugh Senator Admitted Teen GropingÖ https://t.co/zUqD3lNNTPó DRUDGE REPORT (@DRUDGE_REPORT) September 20, 2018Fox News reported†that Bookerís office denied he is guilty of any hypocrisy, and painted the senator as a victim of a ìright-wing attack.îìThis disingenuous right-wing attack, which has circulated online and in partisan outlets for the past five years, rings hollow to anyone who reads the entirety of Senator Bookerís Stanford Daily column,î Bookerís spokesperson said in a statement.ìThe column is in fact a direct criticism of a culture that encourages young men to take advantage of women ñ written at a time when so candidly discussing these issues was rare ñ and speaks to the impact Senator Bookerís experience working to help rape and sexual assault survivors as a college peer counselor had on him,î the spokesperson added.

President Trump delivered a rousing appeal to his supporters to get-out-the-vote for Republican candidates at a rally in Springfield, Missouri on Friday night in support of Missouri Attorney General Josh Hawley, the GOP nominee for the U.S. Senate seat on the ballot this November.The president also strongly supported Judge Brett Kavanaugh, his nominee to serve on the Supreme Court.ìWe have to fight for him, not worry about the other side,î the president said†he told a Republican senator in Washington of Kavanaugh.He also aggressively attacked the platform of the Democrat party.ìThe new platform of the Democrat party is radical socialism and open borders. A vote for any Democrat this November is a vote for massive regulation, massive taxes, and massive crime,î Trump told the large and enthusiastic crowd.ìThe Democrat party is held hostage by angry mobs, ëDeep Stateí radicals and their establishment cronies,î the president continued.ìWeíre going to be fighting [in 2018] to keep what we have,î he added.ìYou canít be complacentî he told the crowd about the 2018 midterm elections.ìGet out in 2018, because youíre voting for me in 2018,î the president said.The current Real Clear Politics Average of Polls shows Hawley and incumbent Sen. Claire McCaskill (D-MO) are statistically tied in a state the president won by 19 percent in 2016.With 46 days until the election, absentee ballot voting (both by mail and in-person) begins in Missouri just four days from Friday, and the stakes in the race could not be higher. Republicans hold a slender 51 to 49 majority in the Senate, and, though the electoral map does not favor Democrats this cycle, they could regain a majority in the upper chamber of Congress with a net pick-up of two seats.Missouri is one of many states where incumbent Democrat senators must hold on in order for the party to accomplish that two-seat net gain. Some optimistic Democrats are eyeing Arizona and Tennessee, which the Cook Political Report currently rate as ìtoss-ups,î as potential Democrat Senate seat flips.The enthused and energetic crowd cheered throughout the entire rendition of Lee Greenwoodís ìGod Bless the USAî as Trump entered the hall.As President Trump stepped to the podium, the crowd broke into chants of ìUSA! USA! USA!îTrump immediately blasted McCaskill and praised Hawley, her Republican opponent.ìMcCaskill voted for the liberal Obama judges who want to destroy your 2nd amendment. They want to destroy your health care, they want to destroy your wealth. They all as a group, they want to raise the hell out of your taxes,î he added.ìShe reveals her true colors when she pretended to tour the state in an RV when she was actually flying around the state in her luxurious private airplane,î Trump said of McCaskill.ìMcCaskill doesnít represent the people of Missouri, she represents the radical Democrats in Washington, D.C. who are trying to take over. Ö Claire McCaskill voted no on tax cuts. And thatís tax cuts for the middle class families,î the president pointed out.Trump continued to run down a long list of bad votes by McCaskill.ìMcCaskill voted no on Kateís Law. How do you vote no on Kateís Law? You know why?† Because Schumer and Pelosi told her,î the president said.ìAnd she voted no on enhanced vetting for refugees. She wants to let everybody pour into our country. She wants to give them free health care Ö McCaskill voted no on our new Supreme Court justice Neil Gorsich. How good is he?î the president asked rhetorically.ìWe need Josh. Ö We have to fight for him,î Trump said of Hawley.ìPlease welcome a special man, a special talent Ö the next United State Senator from Missouri, Josh Hawley,î the president said as he introduced Hawley.ìHow about the leadership of President Donald J. Trump?î Hawley asked, as the crowd responded with loud cheers.ìWe had to turn away about 20,000 people who couldnít get into the stadium,î Hawley told the audience.Other press reports indicated the line to get into the 11,000 capacity stadium extended for as long as two miles.ìHave you noticed something about our president? When he makes a promise he keeps it. When he makes a commitment he delivers. Heís delivering big for the state of Missouri and the United States of America,î Hawley said.The GOP candidate for Senate then turned his attention to the current confirmation battle for Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh.ìThe president said heís going to put pro-Constitution judges on the bench and he has. Judges who love the Constitution. Judges who love our country. Judges like Brett Kavanaugh,î Hawley said.ìThereís somebody in the state of Missouri who hasnít heard what youíve been telling her. Thereís somebody who hasnít been willing to work with the president. That somebody is Claire McCaskill,î he added.ìShe said sheís going to vote no on Judge Kavanaugh,î Hawley said.ìIím not sure who sheís with, but sheís not with the state of Missouri. Ö This November in this state, letís make history again, letís make America great again,î he concluded, turning the podium back to the president.ìJosh is a star. Heís one hundred percent pro 2nd amendment. We need Josh in the Senate to fight for Missouri,î the president said of Hawley.ìWeíll never ever get a vote from Claire McCaskill,î Mr. Trump said, pointing to her promised no vote on Kavanaugh as the most recent example.The president ended the hour and fifteen minutes rally with another push to get out the Republican vote.ìFor years you watched as your leaders apologized for America. Now you have a president who will never apologize for America, but only will stand up for America,î Trump said, adding:We are standing up for your values we standing up for Missouri, and we are standing up for our national anthem.To continue this momentum, to protect your family your jobs and country . . .You need to get out and vote Republican, and vote for Josh Hawley.ìWe are going to win,win, win,î the president said, adding:We will win for our familiesWe will win for our freedomsWe will win for our great American flagWe will not bend we will not break. . .We will always fight on to victory.Our hearts truly bleed red white and blue.We are one people one family and one glorious nation under GodìGo vote for Josh!î were the presidentís closing words as the event ended.

UPDATE: Approximately 90 minutes after the expiration of the 10:00 p.m. deadline, Chairman Grassley took to Twitter, where he made clear that, despite his repeated extensions, he is offering yet another extension to Christine Blasey Fordís legal team, presumably until Saturday, for her to decide whether to testify, in line with attorney Deborah Katzís demands:Five times now we hv granted extension for Dr Ford to decide if she wants to proceed w her desire stated one wk ago that she wants to tell senate her story  Dr Ford if u changed ur mind say so so we can move on I want to hear ur testimony. Come to us or we to uó ChuckGrassley (@ChuckGrassley) September 22, 2018Judge Kavanaugh I just granted another extension to Dr Ford to decide if she wants to proceed w the statement she made last week to testify to the senate  She shld decide so we can move on  I want to hear her.  I hope u understand.  Itís not my normal approach to b indecisiveó ChuckGrassley (@ChuckGrassley) September 22, 2018With all the extensions we give Dr Ford to decide if she still wants to testify to the Senate I feel like Iím playing 2nd trombone in the judiciary orchestra and Schumer is the conductoró ChuckGrassley (@ChuckGrassley) September 22, 2018Lawyers for Judge Brett Kavanaughís accuser, Christine Blasey Ford, refused Friday to reply in time to meet Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassleyís (R-IA) final deadline to agree to have their client testify.Fordís lead attorney, Democratic donor Deborah Katz, sent Judiciary Committee staff an email shortly after 9:00 p.m. refusing to give an answer.ìYour cavalier treatment of a sexual assault survivor who has been doing her best to cooperate with the committee is completely inappropriate,î Katz wrote as she†demanded an additional dayís delay in giving an answer.The new demand comes after almost a full business week since first being offered the opportunity to testify in any one of a number of ways, including in open committee and behind closed doors, as to her allegation that Kavanaugh and another teenager attacked and groped her at a high school party more than 35 years ago.Earlier Friday evening, Grassley had set a 10:00 p.m. deadline, after which he would schedule a committee vote on Kavanaughís Supreme Court confirmation. That 10:00 p.m. Eastern deadline was imposed after Grassleyís relenting from a 10:00 a.m. deadline to let the Judiciary Committee know if Ford would be testifying under oath on Monday. A new date of Wednesday was offered, with an initial deadline to accept of 5:00 p.m., but after rejecting a series of Fordís lawyers controversial demands, a final extension of five hours was offered.Among these demands were a Thursday or later hearing date and a prohibition on the Senate Judiciary Committee enlisting female outside lawyers to assist them in taking Fordís testimony. Most controversially, Fordís legal team demanded that Ford, the accuser, testify after the accused, Kavanaugh. In their final offer letter, Republican Judiciary Committee staff called this demand in a particular ìan affront to fundamental notions of due process.îIf Grassley and his fellow Republicans on the Judiciary Committee stick to their announced plan, the committee will convene for a vote Monday. If, as expected, the Republican majority votes to approve Kavanaughís confirmation, it will pass to the full Senate, where a vote for cloture, setting up a final full-Senate vote, can be taken Wednesday morning. That final vote could then be taken Thursday, allowing Kavanaugh to take a seat on the Supreme Court in time of the start of the Courtís October term.In her Friday night email, Katz insists that ìthe 10 p.m deadline is arbitrary. Its sole purpose is to bully Dr. Ford and deprive her of the ability to make a considered decision that has life-altering implications for her and her family.îTiming in the case, however, has serious implications for Kavanaughís confirmation. Without a hearing Monday, or at the very latest Wednesday, as Grassley had offered, confirming Kavanaugh before the start of the Supreme Courtís new term becomes virtually impossible.

President Donald Trump revealed to his supporters on Friday that he wanted to fight for Judge Brett Kavanaughís nomination to the Supreme Court and ignore the Democrats.The president revealed his feelings about the Senate Judiciary Committeeís decision to delay the vote to confirm Kavanaugh during a political rally with supporters in Missouri.He referred to a conversation he had with a seasoned Republican Senator who tried to explain to him the proper path forward.ìI said, ëWe have to fight for him, not worry about the other side,'î Trump recalled.The Senate Judiciary Committee delayed the vote a week in order to give the woman who accused Kavanaugh of sexual assault a chance to make her case.Trump said the Senator reminded him that he had been in politics for 25 years and knew the right thing to do.ìI said, ëSir, Iíve been in politics for two and a half years and Iím the president of the United States!î Trump said, as the crowd cheered.Trump said that the senator was ìa really good guyî and that they were ìstill friends.îThe crowd chanted ìKavanaugh!î during Trumpís rally, indicating their eagerness to get him confirmed to the Supreme Court.ìBy the way, women are for†that, more than anybody would†understand,î Trump said.†

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-IA) set what he says is the final deadline Friday for Judge Brett Kavanaugh accuser Christine Blasey Fordís lawyers to agree to have her testify at a hearing next week.If Fordís attorneys do not reach an agreement to one of the several options they have been offered for their client to tell her side of the story, Grassley will schedule a committee vote on Kavanaugh for Monday.ìDespite the fact that the July 30th letter remains hidden, my committee has been investigating the allegations and has heard from multiple witnesses since Sunday,î†Grassley said in a statement to reporters after Fordís attorneys, led by Democratic activist Deborah Katz, failed to respond first to a 10:00 a.m. deadline to agree to testify Monday and then a concession offer of 5:00 p.m. to testify Wednesday.The statement continues:Ms. Katz has discussed Dr. Fordís allegations in numerous media interviews and said on TV Monday morning that Dr. Ford wants to share her account with the Senate Judiciary Committee. Itís Friday night and nothingís been agreed to despite our extensive efforts to make testimony possible. Iím extending the deadline for response yet again to 10 oíclock this evening. Iím providing a notice of a vote to occur Monday in the event that Dr. Fordís attorneys donít respond or Dr. Ford decides not to testify. In the event that we can come to a reasonable resolution as Iíve been seeking all week, then I will postpone the committee vote to accommodate her testimony. We cannot continue to delay.Grassleyís move represents the firmest language yet that Senate Republicans have reached the end of their patience since Fordís allegation that Kavanaugh had groped her at a high school party more than 35 years ago threw the confirmation process into disarray last weekend. Grassley set a full public hearing under oath, only for Fordís lawyers to repeatedly not agree to have their client testify.In the intervening time, those lawyers have reportedly issued a fluid set of demands including excluding outside counsel from asking any questions at the hearing, having Ford not be required to appear in the same room as Kavanaugh, testifying in the opposite order of an actual trial with the accuser having the last word and the accused, Kavanaugh, having no opportunity to reply, and finally, Friday, claiming a further delay was needed because Ford was unwilling to board a plane for fear of confined spaces.The Judiciary Committee also released the text of the previous offer, originally made with 5 p.m. deadline, that was put to Fordís lawyers after they failed to meet the 10 a.m. deadline for the Monday hearing. ìThe Chairman has offered the ability for Dr. Ford to testify in an open session, a closed session, a public staff interview, and a private staff interview,î the offer letter explains. ìThe Chairman is even willing to fly female staff investigators to meet Dr. Ford and you in California, or anywhere else, to obtain Dr. Fordís testimony.îThe letter goes on to refuse some of Fordís lawyersí most controversial demands:Some of your other demands, however, are unreasonable and we are unable to accommodate them. You demanded that Judge Kavanaugh be the first person to testify. Accommodating this demand would be an affront to fundamental notions of due process.ÖYou also demanded that only senators be permitted to ask questions of the witnesses. We are also unable to accommodate this demand. There is no rule of the Senate or the Committee that precludes staff attorneys from asking witnesses questions. We reserve the option to have female staff attorneys, who are sensitive to the particulars of Dr. Fordís allegations and are experienced investigators, question both witnesses.ÖYou demanded that the Committee issue subpoenas for the testimony of Mark Judge and other unidentified witnesses. The Committee is unable to accommodate this demand. The Committee does not take subpoena requests from witnesses as a condition of their testimony.ÖYou demanded that the Committee call additional witnesses that Dr. Ford requests. We are unable to accommodate this demand. The Committee does not take witness requests from other witnesses.The Democrats on the Judiciary Committee, led by Ranking Member Dianne Feinstein (D-CA), who withheld a letter detailing Fordís account of her alleged sexual assault for more than six weeks, meanwhile issued a response admonishing Republicans for their handling of the situation. ì[W]e are disheartened to see many of our colleagues in the majority have already made up their minds and begun to dismiss and diminish Dr. Fordís experience,î the Democrats letter reads. ìUp to this point, the Committee majorityís treatment of Dr. Ford has unquestionably been worse than the disgraceful treatment that Anita Hill received 27 years ago.†We are better than this.î

Harvard Law School Professor Emeritus Alan Dershowitz described demands for Judge Brett Kavanaugh to testify before Christine Ford as ìabsurd,î ìoutrageous,î and ìinconceivable.î†He offered his remarks in a Friday interview on SiriusXMís Breitbart News Daily with Breitbart News Editor-in-Chief Alex Marlow.Ford, a California professor, accused Supreme Court nominee Kavanaugh of a ìrape attemptî when both were high schoolers in the 1980s.Dershowitz said, ìItís obvious what should happen. When the accuserís lawyer says that the accused has to go first, thatís such a fundamental denial of due process, the way they used to do it in the Star Chamber, you call somebody in, have him deny everything, and then you bring in the accuser afterward. Thatís just not the way the Anglo-American system of justice has ever worked.îDershwoitz continued, ìIt would be outrageous to have him testify first and her testify only in response, and I want to hear from the American Civil Liberties Union on that issue. Maura Fitzgerald, a friend of Judge Brett Kavanaugh since the two were in high school who briefly dated the future judge in college, defended the Supreme Court nominee along with more than 75 other women at Fridayís ì#IStandWithBrettî press conference.ìI want to make something clear ó very, very clear. The allegation, withheld during Kavanaughís extensive confirmation hearings, has thrown his confirmation process into turmoil and jeopardized his ability to take a seat on the Supreme Court before the October 1 start of the Courtís new term.ìThe allegation against Brett is inconsistent with everything that I have known about him as a person,î Fitzgerald said. ìIn both public and private, Brett treated me and everyone I know with respect. He has always been kind and good-natured. He has always been caring and concerned with the well-being of others.îFitzgerald recounted how Kavanaugh had written her a note offering support when her friend was in a coma after a car wreck. ìThat was very typical of Brett, openly and unabashedly delivering care and compassion,î she said. ìTo my recollection, he was the only friend, male or female, who wrote a note to me after that terrible time.îFitzgerald also recalled Kavanaugh as gracious guest at her parentsí vacation home when they were growing up. ìIt was a full house, but Brett was always welcome. He was polite and considerate to my siblings and to the parents,î she told the audience.ìBrett was the kind of you wanted to take home to meet your parents. Brett was then, and still is, a stand up guy,î Fitzgerald concluded, yielding the podium to the next of the six women who spoke to offer her story of knowing Judge Kavanaugh.

Assorted heads of feminist organizations described Christine Blasey Ford as a ìsurvivorî of sexual assault ó accepting Fordís allegations against Judge Brett Kavanaugh prima facie ó during a Thursday conference hosted by the Feminist Majority Foundation†in Washington, DC.The word ìsurvivorî was used 32 times by the conferenceís featured speakers, according to C-SPANís automated transcription of the event. ìTraumaî was said 23 times.Roger Canaff, a former assistant district attorney in New York City, said a ìreasonable doubt standardî is not needed to block the appointment of Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court:Weíre not dealing with a reasonable doubt standard, either. Thatís really important. We donít need to demonstrate this beyond a reasonable doubt. Judge Kavanaugh is not on trial. This is about whether or not he should have the privilege of serving in the highest court in the United States.Canaff also said Americans must ìstart by believingî all women who make allegations of sexual assault against men:Another thing that we believe in violence against women is to, what we call, ìstart by believingî: SBB. That doesnít mean that we continue to believe despite any fact that might emerge. Ö When we begin by believing survivors, then we allow them to open up their minds. We allow their anxiety to go down, their self-esteem to go up. More facts come forward, we actually reduce bias, and weíre able to get to the truth a lot faster.Indira Henard, executive director of the DC Rape Crisis Center, said Americans must ìbelieveî Fordís accusations against Kavanaugh:It is not our job to dissect Dr. Fordís story or any survivorís story of sexual violence. It is our job to believe them. It is our job to support them. It is our job to hold those responsible accountable. The burden of proof should not be on survivors of sexual violence. Dr. Ford should not be on trial. What we are seeing in the treatment of Dr. Ford is a travesty.Henard warned against senators ìperpetrating another level of violenceî against Ford in the event of Fordís testimony before a Senate committee:If [Christine Blasey Ford] shows up on Monday Ö [senators] are going to be perpetrating another level of violence because itís not going to be a trauma-informed process.We have to be very careful that our institutions are not reperpetrating violence which will be retraumatizing for survivors of sexual violence. Dr. Ford is not just standing as one; she is standing for ten thousand. What is happening to her is also happening to other survivors of sexual violence.Lisalyn Jacobs, an attorney, described Fordís claims as ìserious and credible charges of sexual violence.î She added that ìtime has vindicated [Anita Hill].î She continued:[Ford] is not on trial. Justice demands that we respect that Dr. Ford is a survivor of trauma and that the Senate Judiciary Committee hear from experts on the lasting impact of trauma on survivors. Justice demands that the hearing process be paused while the FBI reopens its investigation.Kiersten Stewart, a director at Futures Without Violence, called on Americaís men to ìbelieve womenî:To the men controlling this process: This is your test, as well. Do you respect women, or donít you? If you do, as you say, then you need to show it with your actions, now, when it matters.ÖTo the men out there: Now is your moment to take a stand. You know sexual violence is wrong. Most of you would never do it and hate is as much as we do. Speak out. Believe women. Use your power. Use your voice. Speak up for a fair process.Toni Van Pelt, president of National Organization for Women (NOW), noted the race and sex of Republican senators on the Senate Judiciary Committee:Only Chuck Grassley and Orrin Hatch still remain on the Senate Judiciary Committee that unfairly interrogated Anita Hill with malice and spitefulness. Ö Dr. Ford made a brave decision to come forward.ìClearly, she is not lying,î added Pelt in reference to Ford.Some women attending the events held signs with the following messages: ì#CancelKavanaugh,î ìI stand with Dr. Christine Blasey Ford,î and ì#IBelieveChristine.îFollow Robert Kraychik on†Twitter.

Christine Blasey Ford, the California psychology professor who has emerged to accuse Judge Brett Kavanaugh of groping her in high school over 35 years ago, wants to move Mondayís scheduled hearing to Thursday instead, among other demands.There is only one possible reason that Dr. Ford and her attorneys could want a Thursday hearing ó not Wednesday, as the GOP has now counter-offered, or Monday as originally scheduled: a Thursday hearing could preclude Kavanaugh from joining the Court for its new session on Oct. 1. (Dr. Ford has until Friday to respond to the counter-offer.)Here is why. The earliest that the Senate Judiciary Committee could vote for Judge Kavanaughís nomination to be considered by the full Senate would be Wednesday afternoon, if the hearing takes place. That would likely mean the earliest that Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) could introduce a motion to confirm Kavanaugh would be Thursday morning. The Senate would then have 24 hours before a cloture motion Friday morning. Then there would be 30 hours of debate, meaning that the earliest that the Senate could vote to confirm Kavanaugh would be Saturday afternoon or evening ó September 29.But if the hearing were Thursday, the earliest the full Senate could vote would be Sunday evening, Sep. 30, with just hours to spare.That would create the very risk that a vote might not be held before Oct. 1, if procedural roadblocks arose (and they would). And some wavering Republicans might be uncomfortable voting to confirm a Supreme Court justice in the dead of night.The only possible reason for Dr. Ford to demand a Thursday hearing (as opposed to Wednesday/Tuesday or the scheduled Monday) is to prevent the Senate from voting to confirm Brett Kavanaugh before month's end, leaving him off the bench when the Supreme Court's next session starts.ó Joel B. Pollak (@joelpollak) September 21, 2018Theoretically, Kavanaugh could join the Court after Oct. 1. But once the Court began its fall session, the Democrats could argue that there is no rush to confirm him, that there should be more investigations, and that the president should let voters decide in November. That would turn the midterm elections into a referendum on the Court, and potentially create a huge political opportunity for Democrats ó and a problem for McConnell and the GOP, who promised a confirmation on time. Republican moderates could start to waver, effectively defeating the nomination ó and infuriating the conservative base.That is why Thursday is so important to Democrats. It also looks less suspicious than demanding a hearing on Friday, or demanding Republicans postpone the process for weeks or more.There is little doubt Ford is coordinating with Democrats. On Thursday, Republicans released the audio of a conference call held by the liberal American Constitutional Society in July with Democratic strategist Ricki Seidman, who is now one of Fordís advisers. In it, she laid out a strategy to defeat the nomination (3:19 to 3:33): ìI do think that over the coming days and weeks there will be a strategy that will emerge, and I think itís possible that that strategy might ultimately defeat the nominee.îFordís accusations ó which were known to ranking member Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-CA) ó have become the ìstrategy that will emerge,î and demanding a Thursday hearing ó not Wednesday, or Monday ó is the way to bring it to fruition.Joel B. Pollak is Senior Editor-at-Large at Breitbart News. He is a winner of the 2018 Robert Novak Journalism Alumni Fellowship. He is also the co-author of†How Trump Won: The Inside Story of a Revolution, which is available from Regnery. Follow him on Twitter at @joelpollak.Matt Boyle contributed to this report.
