The timeline of events following Christine Blasey Fordís decision to go public with her allegations against Judge Brett Kavanaugh can be characterized as a series of solicitous accommodations on the part of the Senate Judiciary Committee and its chairman, followed by shifting demands and stonewalling from Democrats and Fordís lawyers.The letters, statements, and public comments from Senate Republicans and the White House make clear their eagerness for Ford to come forward and be heard before the Senate Judiciary Committee, either in private or in public. At first, Democrats demanded that the accuser be heard. But once Republicans agreed, the goalposts moved, and moved, and moved ó always in the direction of delaying the confirmation vote.The following is a timeline of events.(Editorís†Note: scroll down for the latest updates.)Summer 2018: Christine Blasey Ford, a professor of clinical psychology at Palo Alto University, contacted the Washington Postís tip line after learning that Judge Brett Kavanaugh was on President Trumpís shortlist to replace Justice Anthony Kennedy, the Washington Post reported.The Post also reported that around that same time, Ford contacted Rep. Anna G. Eshoo (D-CA), her representative in Congress.Monday, July 9, 2018: Trump officially nominated Kavanaugh to serve as retiring Justice Kennedyís replacement on the Supreme Court.Late July 2018: According to the Washington Post, in late July, Ford sent a letter through Rep. Eschooís office to Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-CA), the ranking Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee. In the letter, Ford requested anonymity and alleged that Judge Brett Kavanaugh attempted to sexually assault her at a party 35 years ago when they were both teenagers and he was ìstumbling drunkî at the time.Sen. Feinstein did nothing with Fordís letter. She did not alert the Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman, Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-IA), as is customary. She did not alert the Federal Bureau of Investigations (FBI), so that they could include it in their background investigation of the nominee. She did not even alert her fellow Democrats on the Committee.†She would later claim that her lack of action was due to her desire to honor Fordís request for confidentiality.Early August 2018: Ford hired Debra Katz, a lawyer with a long history in Democratic politics who specializes in sexual harassment cases. On Katzís advice, Ford took a polygraph test. The results were later provided to the Washington Post, which reported that the test ìconcluded that Ford was being truthful when she said a statement summarizing her allegations was accurate.îLate August 2018: According to the Washington Post, in Late August, ìFord had decided not to come forward, calculating that doing so would upend her life and probably would not affect Kavanaughís confirmation. ëWhy suffer through the annihilation if itís not going to matter?í she said.îTuesday-Friday, September 4-7, 2018: The Senate Judiciary Committee held confirmation hearings with Kavanaugh from September 4 through 6. On Friday, September 7, they heard expert testimony from Kavanaughís supporters and detractors. This would have been the appropriate venue for Ford to present her accusations. However, if she desired to remain anonymous, Sen. Feinstein could have raised the allegations directly with Kavanaugh during any of the hearings on Tuesday through Thursday. Instead, the hearings concluded without any mention of Fordís allegations.Wednesday, September 12, 2018: Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee ìfirst learned about [Fordís] letterís contents at a meeting called at the last minute†on Wednesday night,î according to the Washington Post. The New York Times reported: ìSeveral Democrats advised [Feinstein] to take [the letterís] claims to the F.B.I., and others pressed for it to become public.îThe story of Fordís letter then†leaked†to the Intercept, which reported that ìDemocrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee have privately requested to view a Brett Kavanaugh-related document in possession of the panelís top Democrat, Dianne Feinstein, but the senior California senator has so far refused, according to multiple sources familiar with the situation.îThursday, September 13, 2018: Feinstein finally issued a statement confirming the existence of the letter but declining to offer any details.ìI have received information from an individual concerning the nomination of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court,î Feinstein wrote. ìThat individual strongly requested confidentiality, declined to come forward or press the matter further, and I have honored that decision. I have, however, referred the matter to federal investigative authorities.îNEW: Sen. Feinstein: ìI have received information from an individual concerning the nomination of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court" and "referred the matter to federal investigative authorities.î pic.twitter.com/ORpIeiNhpIó NBC Politics (@NBCPolitics) September 13, 2018The New York Times reported, ìThe F.B.I. said in a statement on Thursday that it had received Ms. Feinsteinís referral and included it in Judge Kavanaughís background file. A bureau official also said that no criminal investigation had been opened related to the matter.îThe updated copy of Kavanaughís file with the letter was then sent by the White House to Senate Judiciary Chairman Grassley, as is customary.ìIn addition to criminal investigations, the F.B.I. conducts background checks on all major government appointees, including Supreme Court nominees,î the Times noted.The media soon worked itself into a frenzy to discover the name of the accuser and the exact nature of her accusation, which the New York Times said†involved ìpossible sexual misconduct.îFord began to worry that her identity would become public after a Buzzfeed reporter turned up at her home and workplace and another reporter contacted her colleagues.In response to news of the mysterious letter, White House†spokesperson Kerri Kupec issued the following†statement:†ìThroughout his confirmation process, Judge Kavanaugh has had 65 meetings with senatorsóincluding with Senator Feinsteinósat through over 30 hours of testimony, addressed over 2,000 questions in a public setting and additional questions in a confidential.îìNot until the eve of his confirmation has Sen. Feinstein or anyone raised the specter of new ëinformationí about him,î the official added.Friday, September 14, 2018: Ronan Farrow and Jane Mayer of The New Yorker got their hands on the contents of the letter and reported the most accurate description to date of the alleged incident.Sunday, September 16, 2018: Ford went on the record with the Washington Post revealing her name and conveying the entire incident in her own words. She told the Post, ìNow I feel like my civic responsibility is outweighing my anguish and terror about retaliation.îFordís lawyer Debra Katz told the Post: ìVictims must have the right to decide whether to come forward, especially in a political environment that is as ruthless as this one. She will now face vicious attacks by those who support this nominee.îFordís account to the Post also made clear that she was uncertain about key details, such as the exact date of the event, location, and how she got to the party and got home from it. She also revealed that she told no one about the incident until 2012, when she and her husband were in couples therapy. That year, Kavanaughís name was included in a short list of potential Supreme Court nominees for Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney.The notes Fordís therapistís wrote, which the Post acquired in part, contained glaring discrepancies about the incident. The therapist wrote that four boys were involved in the alleged assault, but Ford claimed that only two were: Kavanaugh and his friend, Mark Judge. The therapistís notes also do not contain Kavanaughís name. Ford blamed the discrepancies on the therapistís transcription.The editorial board of Sen. Feinsteinís hometown newspaper, the San Francisco Chronicle, denounced her handling of Fordís allegations, calling it ìunfair all around. It was unfair to Kavanaugh, unfair to his accuser and unfair to Feinsteinís colleagues ó Democrats and Republicans alike ó on the Senate Judiciary Committee.îMonday, September 17, 2018: President Trump said he was open to having the Senate Judiciary Committee delay the confirmation vote to consider Fordís allegation.ìI want the American people to be happy because theyíre getting somebody that is great. I want him to go in at the absolute highest level. And I think to do that you have to go through this. If it takes a little delay, itíll take a little delay,î Trump said.Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley issued the following statement:Anyone who comes forward as Dr. Ford has deserves to be heard, so I will continue working on a way to hear her out in an appropriate, precedented and respectful manner.The standard procedure for updates to any nomineeís background investigation file is to conduct separate follow-up calls with relevant parties.†In this case, that would entail phone calls with at least Judge Kavanaugh and Dr. Ford. Consistent with that practice, I asked Senator Feinsteinís office yesterday to join me in scheduling these follow-ups. Thus far, they have refused. But as a necessary step in evaluating these claims, Iíll continue working to set them up.Unfortunately, committee Republicans have only known this personís identity from news reports for less than 24 hours and known about her allegations for less than a week. Senator Feinstein, on the other hand, has had this information for many weeks and deprived her colleagues of the information necessary to do our jobs. The Minority withheld even the anonymous allegations for six weeks, only to later decide that they were serious enough to investigate on the eve of the committee vote, after the vetting process had been completed.Itís deeply disturbing that the existence of these allegations were leaked in a way that seemed to preclude Dr. Fordís confidentiality.Over my nearly four decades in the Senate I have worked diligently to protect whistleblowers and get to the bottom of any issue. Dr. Fordís attorney could have approached my office, while keeping her client confidential and anonymous, so that these allegations could be thoroughly investigated. Nevertheless, we are working diligently to get to the bottom of these claims.Other Republican senators ó including crucial GOP swing votes ó†agreed with the need to hear from Ford.Sen. Susan Collins (R-ME) said, ìProfessor Ford and Judge Kavanaugh should both testify under oath before the Judiciary Committee.îSen. Jeff Flake (R-AZ), a member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said: ìIf they push forward without any attempt with hearing what sheís had to say, Iím not comfortable voting yes. We need to hear from her. And I donít think Iím alone in this.îSen. Lisa Murkowski (R-AK) said, ìI think [delaying the vote] might be something they might have to consider, at least having that discussion. This is not something that came up during the hearings. And if there is real substance to this, it demands a response.îSen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC), a member of the Judiciary Committee, said, ìIf Ms. Ford wishes to provide information to the committee, I would gladly listen to what she has to say and compare that against all other information we have received about Judge Kavanaugh.îNow that there was general agreement that Fordís testimony should be heard, the Democrats deftly moved the goalposts with a new demand that would delay the confirmation even more. They insisted that the FBI must conduct an investigation into Fordís allegations, despite the fact that the FBI had already fulfilled its obligation in this matter by including Fordís letter in Kavanaughís background file and forwarding it to the White House.Nevertheless, Sen. Feinstein tweeted, ìThereís a lot of information we donít know and the FBI should have the time it needs to review this new material.îSenate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) agreed, tweeting, ì[Senate Republicans] cannot impartially investigate these disturbing allegations. That must be done by the FBI, and the vote must be postponed until it is complete.îSenate Republicans ran a transparently partisan confirmation process and then immediately insinuated Prof Ford is being untruthful. They cannot impartially investigate these disturbing allegations. That must be done by the FBI, and the vote must be postponed until it is complete.ó Chuck Schumer (@SenSchumer) September 17, 2018Senate Judiciary Committee Democrats then sent a letter to Sen. Grassley demanding the vote on Kavanaugh be delayed for an FBI investigation.Their letter stated: ìAs you are aware, Dr. Fordís serious allegations were submitted to the FBI for investigation last week. Now that her story is public, it is even more important that we give the Bureau the time it needs to follow up. All Senators, regardless of party, should insist the FBI perform its due diligence and fully investigate the allegations as part of its review of Judge Kavanaughís background. Staff-level examination of these allegations should not go forward until the FBIís career professionals with the requisite investigative expertise have completed their review. Once the FBI has completed its independent work, we hope that we can work together in a bipartisan manner to decide on next steps.îThe Department of Justice shot down this talking point in a statement issued Monday night, declaring that the FBI can not and will not be investigating Fordís allegation because it†ìdoes not involve any potential federal crimeî and is therefore beyond the FBIís jurisdiction.The statement explained that the FBIís role in conducting a background investigation into a nominee is ìto determine whether the nominee could pose a risk to the national security of the United Statesî and then to provide that information ìfor the use of the decision makers.î The DOJ said, ìitís not the job of the FBI to judge the significance or the credibility of an accusation.îThat afternoon, Sen. Grassley issued a statement that the Judiciary Committee was attempting to reach Ford, who was not responding to their inquiries, but would cancel the confirmation vote scheduled for Thursday, September 20, and instead hold a public hearing on Fordís claim on Monday, September 25.ìAs I said earlier, anyone who comes forward as Dr. Ford has done deserves to be heard. My staff has reached out to Dr. Ford to hear her account, and they held a follow-up call with Judge Kavanaugh this afternoon.† Unfortunately, committee Democrats have refused to join us in this effort.†However, to provide ample transparency, we will hold a public hearing Monday to give these recent allegations a full airing,î†Grassley said.Tuesday, September 18, 2018:†Ignoring the Department of Justiceís prior statements on the matter, Senate Democrats sent a letter to FBI Director Chris Wray and White House Counsel Don McGahn demanding the FBI investigate Kavanaugh.They wrote:†ìThe need for the FBI to perform its due diligence has become even more important in light of Chairman Grassleyís announcement that he plans to move forward with a hearing on this matter next Monday. The Committee should have the completed report before any hearing occurs and we ask that you take immediate steps to make sure that we have the FBIís report before we proceed. Please notify us as soon as possible whether this can be completed in time.îWednesday, September 19, 2018:†Sen. Grassley responded to the Judiciary Committee Democratsí letter with a letter of his own detailing why their demand for an FBI investigation was totally unnecessary now that Fordís allegation has been made public. Such a demand, Grassley explained, was akin to demanding that the FBI do the Senateís job. It is now the duty of the Senate Judiciary Committee to call witnesses, gather evidence, and conduct the investigation going forward, not the FBI.Grassleyís letter stated (emphasis in the original):Your letter requests that I demand that the FBI conduct an additional investigation into this matter. This request demonstrates a fundamental misunderstanding of the FBI background investigation process. Before nominating an individual to a judicial or executive office, the White House directs the FBI to conduct a background investigation. The FBI compiles information about a prospective nominee and sends it to the White House. The White House then provides FBI background investigation files to the Senate as a courtesy to help us determine whether to confirm a nominee. But the FBI does†not†make a credibility assessment of any information it receives with respect to a nominee. Nor is it tasked with investigating those matters that this Committee deems important. The Constitution assigns the Senate, and only the Senate, with the task of advising the President on his nominees and consenting if the circumstances merit. We have no power to commandeer an executive branch agency into conducting†our†due diligence. The job of assessing and investigating a nomineeís qualifications in order to decide whether to consent to the nomination is ours, and ours alone.Second, your request ignores the fact that Dr. Ford has already made her allegations public. The purpose of the background investigation process is to compile information in a†confidential†manner. Confidentiality permits people to speak freely and candidly about the character and qualifications of the nominee. The White House requires the Senate to keep background investigation files private so that people can speak anonymously to investigators if they so desire. Because Dr. Fordís allegations are in the public arena, there is no longer a need for a confidential FBI investigation.In this same letter, Sen. Grassley also†fact-checked the Democratsí claim that their request for an FBI investigation into Fordís allegation is no different than the way the FBI investigated Anita Hillís allegation against Clarence Thomas in 1991. He wrote (emphasis in the original):In 1991, the FBIís additional investigation into Professor Anita Hillís allegations occurred when the allegations were still non-public. When the Senate received Professor Hillís non-public allegations of sexual harassment, then-Chairman Biden expeditiously notified the White House. (That decision sits in sharp contrast to Senator Feinsteinís decision to sit on Dr. Fordís allegations for more than six weeks.) The White House directed the FBI to conduct a handful of interviews regarding Professor Hillís allegations. The FBI completed the interviews within a few days. The White House turned the interview reports over to the Senate as a courtesy. The contents of one of those reports was leaked to the public soon after. The hearing was subsequently reopened†five days†after the allegations were made public.We are in the same position the Committee was in†after†Professor Hillís allegations were leaked.†After that leak, we did not ask the FBI to conduct an investigation. Instead, we reopened the hearing and assessed the testimony that was given on our own. As in 1991, it is now up to the Senate to gather and assess the relevant evidence.On Wednesday, Sen. Grassley also sent a letter to Sen. Feinstein request she provide him and the rest of the Republicans on the Committee a copy of the letter submitted to her by Ford.Grassley wrote, ìMy staff has made repeated requests for this document ó which has become a significant piece of evidence in Judge Kavanaughís confirmation process ó but your staff has so far refused to provide a copy of the letter. You are able to share this unredacted copy with all the members of your caucus and their staff, as well as anyone else you choose. The only version we have of this letter is a redacted version contained in the supplemental FBI background investigation file that only senators and a handful of very select staff are authorized to read.îGrassley then called out Feinsteinís politicization of this process and total disregard for the wellbeing of the accuser, the accused, and her colleagues who want to get at the truth. He wrote (emphasis in the original):Sexual assault allegations deserve serious attention, and those who make such allegations must be heard. They should not be deployed strategically for political gain. You received this letter approximately seven weeks ago. But the contents of the letter were leaked only last week when it appeared the Senate was about to confirm Judge Kavanaugh. There were numerous opportunities to raise the serious allegations made in the letter during the course of this nomination process. They could have been raised in your closed-door meeting with Judge Kavanaugh on August 20. Sixty-four other senators also met with Judge Kavanaugh prior to his confirmation hearing. These senators could have asked Judge Kavanaugh about these allegations if you had shared the letter.Your staff could have raised these allegations during routine background investigation phone calls in late-August. Questions about these allegations could have been asked of Judge Kavanaugh during his more than 32 hours of testimony before the Committee over the course of three days. You could have asked him about these allegations during the closed session of his confirmation hearing, where sensitive material can be discussed. But you did not attend the closed session. Finally, these allegations could have been addressed in one of the nearly 1,300 written questions issued to him after the hearingómore written questions to any Supreme Court nominee than all prior Supreme Court nominees combined.You have said that you didnít raise Dr. Fordís allegations previously because you wanted to protect Dr. Fordís anonymity. But these allegations could have been raised to me, or to Judge Kavanaugh, while protecting Dr. Fordís anonymity. Indeed, the only version of her letter that I have is the redacted version from the FBI, which protected Dr. Fordís anonymity. Had Dr. Ford not made her allegations public via the Washington Post over the weekend, I still would not know her identity. The fact is that these allegations could have been raised both within the last seven weeks and in a way that protected Dr. Fordís anonymity. Instead, you chose to sit on the allegations until a politically opportune moment. I cannot overstate how disappointed I am in this decision. It has caused me to have to reopen the hearings for the fifth day of testimony, when we easily could haveóand should haveóraised these issues before or during the first four days of the hearing.Grassley also made clear that the committee would go out of its way to accommodate Ford so that she could provide her testimony in whatever manner was most comfortable for her ó even going so far as to send his staff to California to get Fordís testimony at her home so that she wouldnít have to travel to D.C.† He†wrote:Dr. Ford has asked for the opportunity to be heard in a hearing, and I believe she should have that opportunity. I recognize that testifying publicly about sexual assault allegations may be difficult for Dr. Ford, so I have offered her the opportunity to testify in any of four possible venues: (1) a public hearing; (2) a private hearing; (3) a public staff interview; or (4) a private staff interview. I am even willing to have my staff travel to Dr. Ford in Californiaóor anywhere elseóto obtain her testimony.Later that day, Fordís lawyer, Debra Katz, sent a letter to Sen. Grassley. Echoing the Senate Democratsí talking points, Katz demanded an FBI investigation on behalf of her client before she would provide any testimony. Katz also objected to any attempt to make her client ìtestify at the same table as Judge Kavanaughî or endure an ìinterrogationî from senators who donít believe her.Katzís letter stated:As you know, earlier this summer, Dr. Ford sought to tell her story, in confidence, so that lawmakers would have a fuller understanding of Brett Kavanaughís character and history. Only after the details of her experience were leaked did Dr. Ford make the reluctant decision to come forward publicly.In the 36 hours since her name became public, Dr. Ford has received a stunning amount of support from her community and from fellow citizens across our country. At the same time, however, her worst fears have materialized. She has been the target of vicious harassment and even death threats. As a result of these kind of threats, her family was forced to relocate out of their home. Her email has been hacked, and she has been impersonated online.While Dr. Fordís life was being turned upside down, you and your staff scheduled a public hearing for her to testify at the same table as Judge Kavanaugh in front of two dozen U.S. Senators on national television to relive this traumatic and harrowing incident. The hearing was scheduled for six short days from today and would include interrogation by Senators who appear to have made up their minds that she is ìmistakenî and ìmixed up.î While no sexual assault survivor should be subjected to such an ordeal, Dr. Ford wants to cooperate with the Committee and with law enforcement officials.As the Judiciary Committee has recognized and done before, an FBI investigation of the incident should be the first step in addressing her allegations. A full investigation by law enforcement officials will ensure that the crucial facts and witnesses in this matter are assessed in a non-partisan manner, and that the Committee is fully informed before conducting any hearing or making any decisions.Sen. Grassley responded in a letter to Fordís attorney, in which he solicitously offered her client the option of a private or public hearing and respectfully explained ó yet again ó why an FBI investigation was wholly unnecessary at this point now that the Senate was conducting its own investigation:As you know, I have reopened the hearing on Judge Kavanaughís nomination in light of Dr. Fordís allegations. That hearing will begin again on Monday, September 24, at 10:00 a.m. I have invited Dr. Ford to testify regarding her allegations against Judge Kavanaugh. And in recognition of how difficult it can be to discuss allegations of this kind in public, I have also offered her the choice of testifying in either a public or closed session of the hearing. In response to my invitation, however, you wrote yesterday that ìan FBI investigation of the incident should be the first step in addressing her allegations.îI certainly understand and respect Dr. Fordís desire for an investigation of her allegations. That is precisely what the Senate is doing. That is why our investigators have asked to speak with your client. That is why I have invited Dr. Ford to tell her story to the Senate and, if she so chooses, to the American people. It is not the FBIís role to investigate a matter such as this. Before nominating an individual to a judicial or executive office, the White House directs the FBI to conduct a background investigation. The FBI compiles information about a prospective nominee and sends it to the White House. The White House then provides FBI background investigation files to the Senate as a courtesy to help us determine whether to confirm a nominee. The FBI does not make a credibility assessment of any information it receives with respect to a nominee. Nor is it tasked with investigating a matter simply because the Committee deems it important. The Constitution assigns the Senate, and only the Senate, with the task of advising the President on his nominee and consenting to the nomination if the circumstances merit. We have no power to commandeer an Executive Branch agency into conducting our due diligence. The job of assessing and investigating a nomineeís qualifications in order to decide whether to consent to the nomination is ours, and ours alone.I have reopened the hearing because I believe that anyone who comes forward with allegations of sexual assault has a right to be heard, and because it is the Committeeís responsibility to fully evaluate the fitness of a nominee to the Supreme Court. I therefore want to give Dr. Ford an opportunity to tell her story to the Senate and, if she chooses, to the American people. I also want to give Judge Kavanaugh an opportunity to respond to the allegations. By hearing out both Dr. Ford and Judge Kavanaugh, the Committee will endeavor to discover the truth of the matter, and will be better able to make an informed judgment about Judge Kavanaughís nomination.Sen. Grassley then provided Katz with a deadline for confirming that her client would testify:You have stated repeatedly that Dr. Ford wants to tell her story. I sincerely hope that Dr. Ford will accept my invitation to do so, either privately or publicly, on Monday. In the meantime, my staff would still welcome the opportunity to speak with Dr. Ford at a time and place convenient to her. And I remind you that, consistent with Committee rules, Dr. Fordís prepared testimony and biography are due to the Committee by 10:00 a.m. on Friday, September 21, if she intends to testify on Monday.A report by Fox News†confirmed Grassleyís assertions that the FBI has no jurisdiction to investigate Fordís allegations because they do not involve a federal crime. An FBI source told the network, ìThis is a political issue, not a law enforcement one.îAnother source told Fox News, ìItís totally inappropriate for someone to demand we use law enforcement resources to investigate a 35-year-old allegation when she wonít go under oath and canít remember key details including when or where it happened.îìIn an FBI background investigation, the bureau is only responsible for finding information and passing it along, which they have done in the Kavanaugh case, a source said. The source said the FBI would not ëinvestigateí the information found,î Fox News reported.However, late Wednesday evening, another of Fordís lawyers, Lisa Banks, issued a new statement that shifted her clientís demands again ó now demanding a hearing for ìmultiple witnesses.îì[Ford] continues to believe that a full non-partisan investigation of this matter is needed and she is willing to cooperate with the Committee,î Banksí statement read. ìHowever, the Committeeís stated plan to move forward with a hearing that has only two witnesses is not a fair or good faith investigation; there are multiple witnesses whose names have appeared publicly and should be included in any proceeding.The rush to a hearing is unnecessary, and contrary to the Committee discovering the truth.îJUST IN: Lawyer for Christine Blasey Ford issues new statement: ìThe rush to a hearing is unnecessary, and contrary to the Committee discovering the truth.î https://t.co/LvTe3kGtgN pic.twitter.com/bocCe54CvHó ABC News (@ABC) September 19, 2018Banks was perhaps alluding to the two other individuals named by Ford as being at the party 35 years ago when the alleged incident occurred. The two men, Mark Judge and†Patrick J. Smyth, both issued statements denying any knowledge of the incident and declining any invitation to speak further on the matter.Mark Judge stated that he had ìno recollection of any of the events describedî by Ford and that he ìnever saw Brett act that way.îIn a letter to Sens. Grassley and Feinstein, Smyth wrote, ìI am issuing this statement today to make it clear to all involved that I have no knowledge of the party in question; nor do I have any knowledge of the allegations of improper conduct she has leveled against Brett Kavanaugh.îìTo safeguard my own privacy and anonymity, I respectfully request that the Committee accept this statement in response to any inquiry the Committee may have,î he added.Thursday, September 20, 2018: On Thursday morning, the Senate Judiciary Committeeís official Twitter account tweeted out confirmation that they had contacted and obtained statements ìunder penalty of felonyî from Kavanaugh, Mark Judge, Patrick J. Smyth, and another person who was allegedly at the party where the incident occurred.In other words, the Committee was, in fact, reaching out to multiple witnesses ó including Cristina King Miranda, a classmate of Fordís who deleted her Facebook post claiming knowledge of the incident and later†admitted, ìThat it happened or not, I have no idea. I canít say that it did or didnít.îWithin hours of learning Dr. Fordís identity from press reports on Sunday Chairman Grassley took swift action making contact w the alleged witnesses. Dems havenít joined background investigation of Dr. Fordís allegations. It's our constitutional duty to do investigations. Join us https://t.co/b2ilr4MRzXó Senate Judiciary (@senjudicia

No word yet on whether they have accepted.Update: The Washington Post†reports that the deadline has now been extended to 10:00 p.m.NEWS
column52: w/@seungminkim: The deadline for Christine Blasey Ford's lawyers to respond to the Senate GOP offer for a Wednesday Judiciary Cmte hearing has been extended until 10 pm tonight

column55: the Committee will proceed with a vote on Monday.Grassleyís statement reads:Despite the fact that the July 30th letter remains hidden
column56: my committee has been investigating the allegations and has heard from multiple witnesses since Sunday. Ms. Katz has discussed Dr. Fordís allegations in numerous media interviews and said on TV Monday morning that Dr. Ford wants to share her account with the Senate Judiciary Committee. Itís Friday night and nothingís been agreed to despite our extensive efforts to make testimony possible. Iím extending the deadline for response yet again to 10 oíclock this evening. Iím providing a notice of a vote to occur Monday in the event that Dr. Fordís attorneys donít respond or Dr. Ford decides not to testify. In the event that we can come to a reasonable resolution as Iíve been seeking all week
column57: then I will postpone the committee vote to accommodate her testimony. We cannot continue to delay.The Senate Judiciary Committee also posted the full proposal sent to Fordís lawyers explaining the Committeeís response to her various demands.The proposal reads:†Rebecca Mansour is a senior editor-at-large for Breitbart News and the host of Breitbart News Tonight on SiriusXMís Patriot channel 125

Rep. Anna Eshoo (D-CA) on Friday discussed how Democrats have handled Dr. Christine Blasey Fordís accusation of sexual assault by Supreme Court justice nominee Brett Kavanaugh being leaked.Eshoo said she has no regrets how the Democrats have handled the allegation†and suggested one of Fordís friends or someone from the community leaked her information.ìI know that Senator Feinstein worked very hard to protect her anonymity,î Eshoo stated, dismissing any blame on the Democrats.ìI donít have regrets, and Iíve thought about this since I met with Dr. Ford,î she said of the handling of the accusation. ìNo one is perfect, but I think that my sharing with her that I was not there to tell her what to do, but rather do what she wished me to do, if she chose to Ö do something else.îFollow Trent Baker on Twitter†@MagnifiTrent

In an interview that aired Friday on NBCís ìToday,î former Vice President Joe Biden weighed in on the sexual misconduct allegation against Supreme Court justice nominee Brett Kavanaugh.Biden said, like with Anita Hill during Clarence Thomasí confirmation, the FBI should do an investigation, adding he hopes Kavanaughís accuser, Dr. Christine Blasey Ford, is not ìvilifiedî in the same way Hill was.ìAnita Hill was vilified when she came forward, by a lot of my colleagues ó character assassination. I wish I could have done more to prevent those questions, the way they asked them,î Biden told NBC Newsí Craig Melvin. ìI hope my colleagues learned from that.îFollow Trent Baker on Twitter†@MagnifiTrent

A group of six women who have known Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh personally or professionally dating back to his school days will speak at an ì#IStandWithBrettî press conference at the JW Marriott hotel in Washington, DC, Friday.The conference is held as Kavanaugh faces a sexual assault allegation never publicly revealed in the 35 or more years since the attack allegedly occurred. Accuser Christine Blasey Ford claims a 17-year-old Kavanaugh and another teenager forced her into a room and groped her in or around 1982 at a high school party.The women of the†#IStandWithBrett event will add to numerous people that have already made statements that the accusation does not match the character of the Brett Kavanaugh they have known for years. The six women met Kavanaugh at various stages of his life, including in high school days in which Ford claims he attacked her.According to a release from organizers, the women include:The conference is set to begin at 11 a.m. Eastern, with the livestream beginning shortly thereafter.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) predicted during the Values Voters Summit on Friday that ìJudge Kavanaugh will be on the Supreme Court.îSen. McConnell predicted that the Senate will soon confirm President Donald Trumpís Supreme Court nominee on Friday despite the accusations laid against Kavanaugh. Christine Blasey Ford, a California psychology professor, has accused Kavanaugh of sexually assaulting her when they were both in high school in the 1980s.Ford†alleges†that in 1982, 17-year-old†Kavanaugh and a friend pulled Ford into a room during a high school party in suburban Maryland, forced her onto a bed, and groped her over her clothing before she was able to escape.McConnell continues to back Kavanaugh, saying that ìPresident Trump has nominated a stunningly successful individual.îSen. McConnell charged that Senate Republicans must ìwait out the obstructionî from Senate Democrats and that Kavanaugh will soon join President Trumpís other nominee, Neil Gorsuch, on the Supreme Court.The Kentucky Republican said, ìYouíve watched the fight. Youíve watched the tactics. But hereís what I want to tell you: in the very near future, Judge Kavanaugh will be on the United States Supreme Court,î to which the crowd erupted in thunderous applause.ìSo my friends, keep the faith. Donít be rattled by all of this. Weíre going to plow right through it and do our jobs,î McConnell added.ìEven more nominees will be confirmed. They will be pro-family,î said McConnell.
McConnell also said that the record numbers of judicial confirmations are the ìsingle most consequential thingsî the Senate does for the future of the country.President Trump backed the Supreme Court nominee in a series of tweets on Friday, saying, ìJudge Brett Kavanaugh is a fine man, with an impeccable reputation, who is under assault by radical left-wing politicians who donít want to know the answers, they just want to destroy and delay. Facts donít matter. I go through this with them every single day in D.C.îTrump also called for Ford to provide details of Kavanaughís alleged assault against her.ìI have no doubt that, if the attack on Dr. Ford was as bad as she says, charges would have been immediately filed with local Law Enforcement Authorities by either her or her loving parents,î Trump added. ìI ask that she bring those filings forward so that we can learn date, time, and place!îJudge Brett Kavanaugh is a fine man, with an impeccable reputation, who is under assault by radical left wing politicians who donít want to know the answers, they just want to destroy and delay. Facts donít matter. I go through this with them every single day in D.C.ó Donald J. I ask that she bring those filings forward so that we can learn  date, time, and place!ó Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) September 21, 2018

Ford has said she did not report the details of the alleged incident to anyone after she claims it occurred†over 30 years ago when they were both in high school.Trump ridiculed the left for demanding an FBI investigation of the alleged incident before confirming Kavanaugh.ìThe radical left lawyers want the FBI to get involved NOW,î he wrote. ìWhy didnít someone call the FBI 36 years ago?îTrump also expressed his frustration with the Democrats and leftists in Washington, DC, after they successfully delayed the vote to confirm his nominee by a week.ìJudge Brett Kavanaugh is a fine man, with an impeccable reputation, who is under assault by radical left-wing politicians who donít want to know the answers, they just want to destroy and delay,î he wrote. ìFacts donít matter. I go through this with them every single day in D.C.îTrump criticized Sen. Thursday on her MSNBC show, Rachel Maddow discussed Supreme Court justice nominee Brett Kavanaughís sexual assault accusation, and if confirmed, she said the judge could be arrested as a sitting Supreme Court justice because ìthere is no statute of limitations for a felony like thisî where the alleged misconduct allegedly took place over 30 years ago.ìThere is no statute of limitations for a felony like this in Maryland,î Maddow explained. ìLocal authorities in Montgomery County, Maryland now say that while this allegation does pertain to their jurisdiction, the reason they have not yet opened a criminal investigation of this matter is because they have not received a criminal complaint from the alleged victim in this case. I donít know if it will always be this way.îShe added, ì[Dr. Christine Blasey Ford] could, at any point, make that criminal complaint to the police in Maryland, who would not be bound by some expiration of the statute of limitations here. Such a complaint count start a criminal investigation conceivably of a sitting Supreme Court justice for felony attempted rape. If law enforcement found that allegation to be substantiated and they found sufficient evidence to bring charges, there is no rule against indicting a Supreme Court justice. There is not even a Justice Department policy against indicting a Supreme Court justice the way there is for, say, a president of the United States.îFollow Trent Baker on Twitter†@MagnifiTrent

Left-wing activists held small rallies on Thursday in support of Christine Blasey Ford, the psychology professor who has emerged to accuse Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett Kavanaugh of groping her at a high school party over 35 years ago.In Palo Alto, California, about two dozen activists, mostly women, marched to Dr. Fordís house, carrying signs such as ìWe Support We Believe,î ìGrateful 4 Christine,î and ìStand for Sexual Peace.îPhotos: Palo Alto moms rally in support of Christine Blasey Ford https://t.co/Ag9BXEpGG7 pic.twitter.com/HZtH5PX9oqó East Bay Times (@EastBayTimes) September 20, 2018CBS San Francisco reported:About two dozen neighbors of Ford marched to her Palo Alto home and stood in the driveway in a symbolic show of support and protection.ìWeíve got her back. Her story is our story. She is one of us,î said neighbor Kristen Podulka.At the same time, an airplane ó reportedly hired by a different group of activists from back east ó was flying above Palo Alto towing the message, ìThank you Christine, we have your back.îìSheís getting death threats. The trolls of the world are not afraid to have their voice spoken,î said Poduika. ìSo we are trying to drown them out with our voice of love and encouragement and support.îPalo Alto Mayor Liz Kniss encouraged Dr. Ford to testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee, though Dr. Fordís lawyer is insisting on a number of conditions before she does so, including that she be allowed to testify after Kavanaugh.In Washington, DC, activists gathered in the Hart Senate Office Building to protest against Kavanaugh. Wearing buttons that read, ìI believe Dr. Christine Blasey Ford,î they cheered Democrat Sens. Mazie Hirono (D-HI) and Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY).Joel B. Pollak is Senior Editor-at-Large at Breitbart News. He is a winner of the 2018 Robert Novak Journalism Alumni Fellowship. He is also the co-author of†How Trump Won: The Inside Story of a Revolution, which is available from Regnery. Follow him on Twitter at @joelpollak.

If you like what youíve seen Democrats do in the Brett Kavanaugh hearings, youíre going to love what they do if they win the 2018 midterm elections.They began by trying to prevent the hearings from taking place at all, interrupting repeatedly and demanding votes on frivolous points of order.Then they praised the left-wing radical ìprotestersî who disrupted proceedings.Then they broke the rules and released confidential information.Now, they want Kavanaugh to face a Kafkaesque show trial.The Democrats are doing their worst because a Supreme Court seat is at stake, and their base will accept nothing less. Yet they will do the same next year, if voters give them a chance to govern again.They intend on turning the House ó or the Senate ó into a Star Chamber that could make the McCarthy hearings look like a model of procedural fairness.They are not interested in oversight, any more than they want to hear from Christine Blasey Ford. They want to turn oversight into ìoverthrow.îMcClatchy briefly sketched Democratsí plans Thursday:Democrats want to examine President Donald Trumpís tax returns. Thereís talk of launching an independent commission into his administrationís handling of the hurricane that wracked Puerto Rico. Progressive activists are ready to start impeachment proceedings.Get ready. If Democrats take control of a chamber in the November election, expect a flood of hearings, investigations, probes and special commissions starting in January.Last month, a spreadsheet emerged that listed 100 investigations that Republicans believe Democrats will launch the moment Nancy Pelosi seizes the speakerís gavel. Many of them are redundant, or ridiculous, aimed only at embarrassing the president and preventing Congress from achieving anything more on his watch.For example, Democrats want to probe the payment to porn star Stormy Daniels ó a matter already in the ambitious grasp of the U.S. Attorney of the Southern District of New York.The ultimate goal is Trumpís impeachment, removal of office ó and, perhaps, worse. House Minority Whip Steny Hoyer (D-MD), the second-ranking Democrat behind Pelosi, has†declared Trump guilty of ìtreason,î for which one punishment is death.Pelosi has tried to downplay the impeachment issue, without success, because the so-called ìResistanceî demands nothing less and because Tom Steyer, the partyís top donor in the last midterm election, is spending over $100 million promoting the cause.But even if Democrats do not succeed in ousting Trump ó thanks, in theory, to Republican opposition in the Senate ó they will destroy our democratic institutions in the process.In the Kavanaugh controversy, Democrats are backing a demand by Dr. Fordís attorney that the judge be required to speak†first ó before he has heard the accusations against him. It is a complete inversion of civil rights, one familiar to totalitarian dictatorships, and a preview of how Democrats will conduct ìoversight.îDemocrats have also demanded the FBI investigate Kavanaugh, for a seventh time. They have learned nothing from 2016 and are eager to use ó or abuse ó the powers of law enforcement for political gain.†And Sen. Mazie Hirono (D-HI) helpfully offered this advice to American men: ìJust shut up.îSen. Dianne Feinstein (D-CA),†who is chiefly to blame for the way Democrats have handled the Kavanaugh accusation, was elected in 1992, after female voters marched to the polls to express their outrage at the way Anita Hill was questioned about her accusations against Clarence Thomas. She has predicted†2018 will be another ìyear of the woman,î and is determined to make it so.But there are also millions of American men ó and women ó who are outraged by what is happening to Kavanaugh. It is up to them to stop this liberal totalitarianism from taking over our country.Joel B. Pollak is Senior Editor-at-Large at Breitbart News. He is a winner of the 2018 Robert Novak Journalism Alumni Fellowship. He is also the co-author of†How Trump Won: The Inside Story of a Revolution, which is available from Regnery. Follow him on Twitter at @joelpollak.

Politico Editor-in-Chief John Harris penned an op-ed on Monday suggesting that ìGod is laughing at Brett Kavanaugh,î noting the supposed irony that Kavanaugh once investigated Bill Clintonís infidelity only to have the Senate Judiciary Committee and the media now investigate a sexual misconduct allegation brought against the Supreme Court nominee.Harris wrote his op-ed one day after the Washington Post revealed that California psychology professor, Christine Blasey Ford, is the woman that now accuses Supreme Court Justice nominee Judge Brett Kavanaugh of sexually assaulting her when they were both in high school in the 1980s.Ford alleges that back in 1982, a 17-year-old†Kavanaugh and a friend of his pulled Ford into a room during a high school party in suburban Maryland, forced her onto a bed, and groped her over her clothing before she was able to escape.The Politico chief noted the irony in this accusation considering that Kavanaugh spent his early 30s investigating Bill Clintonís ìmost intimate moral failings,î or his affair with then-21-year-old White House intern Monica Lewinsky. And now the Senate Judiciary Committee and the media are investigating Kavanaughís alleged groping of a woman when he was in high school.ìGod, itís sometimes said, has an awesome sense of humor,î Harris remarked.The Politico head continued:So here was Kavanaughówho spent his early 30s as a Ken Starr warrior pursuing Bill Clinton for the political and legal implications of his most intimate moral failingsónow in his early 50s facing a political crisis over disturbingly vivid, passionately contested, decades-old allegations about Kavanaughís own possible moral failings.Few prosecutors, it seems likely, would ever open an assault caseó36 years lateróon the basis of Christine Blasey Fordís account of being pinned down on a bed by a drunken Kavanaugh, then 17, and being aggressively groped until a friend of his physically jumped in.Harris contends that few people would investigate a 36-year-old sexual assault accusation; however, few people would have also investigated a ìmiddle-aged manís lies about adultery if that person had not been President Bill Clinton.î The Politico chief†neglects to mention that President Clinton was impeached for lying under oath before a grand jury and for obstruction of justice, not for sexual impropriety.The comparison between Kavanaugh and Clinton also fails to note that President Clinton did, in fact, have an affair with Lewinsky during his presidency, while Kavanaugh has continued to vehemently deny the accusations brought against him.Now on Thursday, Ford has said that she is willing to testify before the committee next week, but not on Monday, ìso long as her safety is assured and hearing is fair.îNEW: Lawyers for Christine Blasey Ford have told Senate Judiciary Committee staff she is "prepared to testify" next week ó but not Monday ó so long as her safety is assured and hearing is fair.  My latest.  https://t.co/WiA3kXb2d8ó Sheryl Gay Stolberg (@SherylNYT) September 20, 2018Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-IA) gave Ford and her lawyers until Friday morning to say if she plans to testify either in private or public.Sen. Marco Rubio (R-FL) suggested that, if Ford does not testify, the committee should move forward with Kavanaughís nomination, and key moderate senators are beginning to say the same.President Donald Trump said on Wednesday that he would like to hear from Kavanaughís accuser despite her reluctance to testify. The president also said that the last-minute accusation revealed by Democrats was ìvery unfairî to Kavanaugh and his family.ìI can only say this: He is such an outstanding man. Very hard for me to imagine that anything happened,î Trump added.Harris concludes in his editorial, ìWith a vote on his career-long dream of serving on the high court scheduled for three days from now, Kavanaugh can be forgiven if he is not in an ironic frame of mind.î

President Donald Trump on Thursday evening said Democrats are trying to ìbesmirchî Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh and need to ìget on with itî without any more Senate Judiciary Committee delays.ìI donít think you can delay it any longer. Theyíve delayed it a week already,î Trump told Fox News host Sean Hannity before a Las Vegas, Nevada, rally. ìThey have to get on with it.îBefore the rally, Trump told Hannity that he thinks ìitís a sad situationî and said that Kavanaugh is an ìoutstanding person.î Trump, referring to Christine Blasey Ford, the Northern California psychology professor who has accused Kavanaugh of sexual assault, asked, ìWhy didnít somebody call the FBI 36 years ago?îìTo take a man like this and besmirch,î Trump said, adding that he has been ìaccommodating.î ìNow, with that being said, let her have her say and letís see how it all works out.îLater at the rally for Sen. Dean Heller (D-NV), Trump said, ìOne of the reasons I was elected was because you believed I was going to pick great Supreme Court Justices.îìBrett Kavanaughóand Iím not saying anything about anybody elseóbut I want to tell you that Brett Kavanaugh is one of the finest human beings you will have the privilege of knowing or meeting. A great intellect. A great gentleman. An impeccable reputation. Went to Yale. Top student. Went to Yale Law School. Top student,î Trump said at the rally. ìSo weíll let it play out, and I think everythingís going to be just fine. This is a high-quality person.îOn Thursday afternoon, Fordís lawyers told Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-IA) that though Ford will not testify on Monday, Ford ìwishes to testify, provided that we can agree on terms that are fair and which ensure her safety.îìA hearing on Monday is not possible and the Committeeís insistence that it occur then is arbitrary in any event,î Fordís lawyers wrote Grassley, who had given Fordís team a Friday morning (10 a.m. ET) deadline to make their decision about testifying. ìDr. Ford has asked me to let you know that she appreciates the various options you have suggested. Her strong preference continues to be for the Senate Judiciary Committee to allow for a full investigation prior to her testimony.îKavanaugh also wrote Grassley and said he ìwill be thereî on Monday and looks ìforward to the opportunity to testify before the Committee.îìI continue to want a hearing as soon as possible, so that I can clear my name,î Kavanaugh wrote. ìSince the moment I first heard this allegation, I have categorically and unequivocally denied it.†I remain committed to defending my integrity.îOn Thursday evening, Fordís lawyers reportedly indicated that Ford could be willing to testify on Thursday of next week so long as certain conditions are met. Fordís lawyers reportedly are opposed to Senators using outside lawyers to question Ford. They also want Kavanaugh to testify first and to not be in the same room at the same time as Ford.Earlier in the week, Lisa Banks, one of Fordís lawyers, told CNNís Anderson Cooper that her client was ìnot preparedî to testify on Monday and indicated that Ford did not want to do so before a full FBI investigation into her allegations. Banks also claimed that the Judiciary Committeeís ìstated plan to move forward with a hearing that has only two witnesses is not a fair or good faith investigationî and added that ìthere are multiple witnesses whose names have appeared publicly and should be included in any proceeding.î

President Donald Trump signaled Friday that he was growing impatient with the delays over the vote to confirm Judge Brett Kavanaugh as his Supreme Court nominee.ìI donít think you can delay it any longer,î Trump said in an interview with Fox News host Sean Hannity. ìTheyíve delayed it a week already.îThe Senate Judiciary Committee delayed the vote after Christine Ford accused Kavanaugh of sexual assault over 30 years ago when they were both in high school.Trump said he was willing to hear testimony from Ford, despite her reluctance to appear in front of the Senate Judiciary Committee on Monday.ìLet her have her say, and letís see how it all works out,î he said.Trump questioned why the allegations were not made public sooner and said that it was a ìsad situationî for Kavanaugh, who is a great man.The president mentioned the Kavanaugh situation during his rally in Las Vegas on Thursday night.ìOh look at our judges, what is going on?î he exclaimed, prompting an angry roar from the energetic crowd as they shouted ìKavanaugh!îTrump supporters in Las Vegas chant "Kavanaugh!" after the president asks, "Look at our judges! What's going on?" pic.twitter.com/DEE0EI0VFxó Charlie Spiering (@charliespiering) September 21, 2018Trump did not attack the accuser, focusing instead on the integrity of Kavanaugh.ìI am not saying anything about anyone else, but I want to tell you that Brett Kavanaugh is one of the finest human beings you will ever have the privilege of knowing or meeting,î he said.Trump urged his supporters to be patient.ìWeíll let it play out and I think everything will be just fine,î he said.

During an interview on the Fox News Channel on Thursday, President Trump stated that Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett Kavanaugh is an ìoutstandingî individual, Kavanaughís accuser, Dr. Christine Blasey Ford should have her say, and Kavanaughís confirmation canít be delayed any longer.Trump said, ìI think itís a very sad situation. Heís an outstanding person. And frankly, Sean, to see whatís going on is just very, very sad. You say, why didnít somebody call the FBI 36 years ago? I mean, you could also say, when did this all happen, whatís going on? To take a man like this and besmirch ó now, with that being said, let her have her say, and letís see how it all works out. But I donít think you can delay it any longer. Theyíve delayed it a week already. Ö I say, let her say what she has to say, and letís see how it all comes out. But theyíve delayed it a week, and they have to get on with it.îFollow Ian†Hanchett on Twitter†@IanHanchett

Ricki Seidman, a longtime Democrat operative, is advising Christine Blasey Ford, the†California professor who recently came forward with 36-year-old sexual misconduct allegations against Supreme Court Nominee Judge Brett Kavanaugh.In an interview with Politico Thursday, Seidman confirmed she is helping Ford work through the process of arranging a potential hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee.†Chairman Chuck Grassley requested Ford confirm by 10 a.m. Friday whether she will†appear before lawmakers on Capitol Hill on Monday and has also offered to send staffers to interview her in California.ìI believe her and I think sheís very courageous for coming this far,î Seidman told the news outlet.Prior to her post as senior principal at TSD Communications,†Seidman†was then-Senator Joe Bidenís communications director in 2008 and later advised the White House on the confirmation hearings of Supreme Court nominee Judge†Sonia Sotomayor in 2009. The longtime Democrat operative was also the deputy communications director during the Clinton years.One Republican official told Politico that†Seidmanís involvement ìfeels more like a Democratic super PAC than a legal effort to get at the truth.îAn email obtained by the New York Times reveals Ford has declined to testify on†Monday†and is instead proposing to appear before lawmakers on an unspecified day next week if given ìterms that are fair and which ensure her safety.î Appearing before the committee ìis not possible and the Committeeís insistence that it occur then is arbitrary in any event,î the email written by Fordís lawyer reads.In an interview with the†Washington Post†released over the weekend, Ford came forward with her allegations against Kavanaugh, in which she claimed the future judge pinned her down on a bed and proceeded to grope her during a Maryland house party in the 1980s.†Ford reportedly does not recall who organized the gathering or its exact time and date.Mike Judge, who Ford claims jumped atop her and Kavanaugh sending the pair tumbling to the ground, told the†Weekly Standard that the accusation is†ìabsolutely nuts.îLast Monday, Kavanaugh denied the allegation, issuing the following statement: ìThis is a completely false allegation. I have never done anything like what the accuser describesóto her or to anyone. Because this never happened, I had no idea who was making this accusation until she identified herself yesterday. îConversing with reporters this week, President Donald Trump defended Kavanugh, describing him as an ìoutstanding man,î and encouraged Ford to appear before lawmakers next week.ìLook, if she shows up and makes a credible showing, that will be very interesting and weíll have to make a decision,î the president said. ìBut I can only say this: heís such an outstanding man ó very hard for me to imagine that anything happened.îìI really want to see her,î he added.

Thursday at a Capitol Hill press conference, Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY) said Republicans were not giving ìbasic courtesiesî to Christine Blasey Ford, who has accused Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh of sexual misconduct.Gillibrand said. ìI believe Dr. Blasey Ford because she is telling the truth and you know it by her story, by the fact she told her therapist from five years ago. It was documented at the time. We have the therapistís notes. She told her husband. This is a trauma she has been dealing with her whole life. She doesnít want to be in a bedroom that doesnít have two doors. People knew that about her a long time ago. They told a friend a year ago before Kavanaugh was ever named. These are the hallmarks of truth. These are the hallmarks of someone who has to be believed.îShe continued, ìShe fears if this person is confirmed he will do terrible things for American women. She is concerned he doesnít have the character, the integrity, the honesty to be a Supreme Court justice. I believe her because sheís telling the truth. Sheís asking the FBI to investigate her claims. Sheís asking for that kind of review, that investigative work, that oversight and accountability, because sheís telling the truth. Someone who is lying does not ask the FBI to investigate their claim. Who is not asking the FBI to investigate these claims? The White House. Even the Anita Hill hearing had an investigation, an FBI investigation, of her allegation in advance of the hearing. She had 22 witnesses, some of them corroborating witnesses. Those things are not being afforded Dr. Blasey Ford. They are the basics. This is not something thatís debatable or negotiable, or we only do it sometime. Vice President Mike Pence said on Wednesday that he and President Donald Trump want to hear from Christine Blasey Ford ó the woman who has accused Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh of attacking her in high school ó but that the ìprocessî the Democrats have used to put last-minute doubt into the confirmation process has been unfair to Kavanaugh and his family.ìLet me just say to begin with that I had the opportunity to meet Judge Kavanaugh before the president made a decision, and to review his record,î Pence told Tony Perkins, president of the Family Research Council on his Washington Watch radio program. Pence went on to say:Judge Brett Kavanaugh is a man of integrity, deeply committed to his family, with a lifetime of service to this country in a variety of roles. On the District of Columbia Court of Appeals more than 300 opinions that reflect a strong and principled judicial philosophy that again interprets statutes as written, will interpret the Constitution as written, will not legislate from the bench, and we believe that he will make an outstanding justice to the Supreme Court of the United States.That being said, as President Trump has said over the last several days, with the allegations that have emerged, itís important that we give it time, that we hear from both sides, and we have every confidence that Senator Grassley and the Republicans in the Senate will handle these allegations properly. I know Senator Grassley has laid forward a range of options from an open session hearing to a closed session to private staff interviews, and theyíve already ó the staff and the judiciary committee has already begun following up on leads ó following Dr. Fordís allegations. And thatís all very important.And again ó weíre confident the Senate will handle it, but that being said, what Senator Diane Feinstein has done here ó what Democrats in the Senate have done here ó is very unfair to Judge Brett Kavanaugh and it is a great disservice to the process. The fact that Senator Feinstein apparently had this letter more than six weeks ago, never raised the issue in her interview with Judge Brett Kavanaugh, never brought the issue to the attention of other members of the judiciary committee, itís a great disservice to the process, and to the American people, and, of course, to Judge Brett Kavanaugh and his family.Pence also said the Democratic senators on the Judiciary committee also harmed the confirmation process by how they handled questioning Kavanaugh at the hearings.ìAnd frankly, it follows on conduct by many Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee who I think virtually embarrassed themselves during the public hearings that were on display just a few short days ago,î Pence said. ìSo, that being said, I would just say the president and I believe that Judge Brett Kavanaugh will make an outstanding addition to the Supreme Court of the United States.îìWeíre very confident that the Senate will handle this all in a proper and appropriate way,î Pence said.Follow Penny Starr on Twitter

Two witnesses back him up.To bring Kavanaugh down, the media are currently throwing whatever it can against the wall in the hopes of peeling off enough moderate Republican senators to kill his confirmation chances.And for that reason, a wildly misleading HuffPost headline reads, ìBrett Kavanaugh Liked Female Clerks Who Looked A ëCertain Way,í Yale Student Was Told.îBut if you actually read the story, that is not even close to the truth.Naturally, the truth is buried under a dozen or so paragraphs of innuendo.The storyís opening makes it sound as though Kavanaugh is grooming female law clerks for something untoward:A few years ago, as she was prepping to interview for a judicial clerkship, a student at Yale Law School received a troubling combination of warning and advice from her professors about one federal judge in particular: Brett Kavanaugh, she was told, liked his female clerks to have a ìcertain look.îHuffPost then links the Kavanaugh dress code ìwarningî to former appeals court judge Alex Kozinski, who retired last year under a cloud of harassment allegations: ì[She was warned] about two judges in particular: First, Alex Kozinski, then a judge on the U.S. 9th Circuit Court of Appeals, was known to sexually harass his clerks, he told her. (Kozinski retired in December amid accusations of harassment.)îAt first, HuffPost tells us this anonymous woman did not know what that ìcertain lookî was, stating only ìIt was very clear to me that he was talking about physical appearance, because it was phrased as a warning <U+2015> and because it came after the warning about Judge Kozinski.îBut a full fifteen paragraphs into the piece, we discover that she was, in fact, told what a ìcertain lookî meant.It meantÖìOutgoing.îYes, you read that correctly; people are telling budding law clerks that Brett Kavanaugh wants female law clerks to look ìoutgoing,î which the dictionary defines as ìfriendly and socially confident; extroverted.îMerriam-Webster uses ìoutgoingî this way in a sentence: ìHis†outgoing†personality made him popular at school.îIn other words, you should dress for success, with confidence, sharp, ready to conquer the world, to succeed Ö and not like a granola with a chip on your shoulder.Moreover, the person giving this ìoutgoingî advice is Ö a woman. Her name is Amy Chau, and she is a Yale Law School professor. The other person offering the advice is Chauís husband, Jed Rubenfeld, also a Yale professor.Without explanation, HuffPost describes Chau as ìcontroversial.îSomehow, though, the HuffPost story gets worse.A full 16 paragraphs in, we learn this advice might have been meant especially for this anonymous woman.ìThe woman said she was not sure if Chua was giving this advice to others,î HuffPost is forced to admit.ìA friend suggested that the student needed the advice because she was ëawkward,í according to a transcript of a Gchat conversation that the Yale student had at the time and that was viewed by HuffPost.îAnd so, if you read between the lines, it sounds as though this anonymous law student dressed like a slob, and a couple of concerned professors, hoping to advance her career, brought this to her attention in the most diplomatic way possible.For her part, Chau supports Kavanaughís nomination and says she has placed ten clerks with him over the years, eight of them women, one of them her own daughter.ìAs I wrote in the Wall Street Journal, he has also been an exceptional mentor to his female clerks,î Chau told HuffPost. ìAmong my proudest moments as a parent was the day I learned our daughter would join those ranks.îA full 22 paragraphs into the piece, HuffPost finally informs readers, ìGiving law students advice on what to wear to an interview isnít terribly odd.îOf course, this is followed by a ìbut.îìÖbut the particular warning about Kavanaugh is unusual.îA columnist told HuffPost the advice is ìsexist.îExcept it is not Kavanaugh offering the advice; it is a professional woman motivated to help other women.Oh, and despite her misgivings about appearing ìoutgoing,î despite her ìmixed feelingsî about Kavanaugh, this anonymous woman still interviewed with him.Obviously, she did not get the job.Just one week ago, according to the media, Kavanaugh was a teenage ìrapist.î Now the media are reduced to publishing misleading headlines, followed by a pile of dishonest paragraphs that are only there to bury the inconvenient truth of Kavanaughís stellar record when it comes to advancing the careers of ìoutgoingî women.†Follow John Nolte on Twitter @NolteNC. Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-IA) sent a letter on Wednesday to California psychology professor Christine Blasey Ford saying she has until Friday to tell whether she intends to testify before the committeeís hearing on Monday regarding her accusation that Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh sexually assaulted Ford when they were both in high school.Chairman Grassley sent a letter to Fordís lawyers, requesting Grassley to either testify in public or private before the committee on Monday.Ford has so far declined to say whether she will testify Monday and instead asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) to investigate the case; The agency has declined to do so.Ford now alleges that back in the 1980ís, a 17-year-old†Kavanaugh and a friend of his allegedly pulled Ford into a room during a high school party in suburban Maryland, forced her onto a bed and groped her over her clothing before she was able to escape.Grassley said Tuesday that Mondayís hearing with Ford and Kavanaugh could be canceled if Ford does not testify on Monday, suggesting that it would be pointless without her testimony.Chairman Grassley asked rhetorically, ìDo they want to have the hearing or not? Weíre delaying the vote strictly to get all the facts out on the table. What would be the purpose of the hearing if Dr. Ford doesnít want to respond?îIn the letter to Fordís lawyers, Grassley rebuked the call for an FBI investigation into her allegation against Kavanaugh, stating that the FBI has already conducted a background check into any executive or judicial nominee. Instead, the Senate Judiciary Committee chairman contended that only the Senate could determine the worthiness of a Supreme Court nominee.Grassley explained:The Constitution assigns the Senate, and only the Senate, with the task of advising the President on his nominee and consenting to the nomination if the circumstances merit. We have no power to commandeer an Executive Branch agency into conducting our due diligenence. The job of assessing and investigating a nomineeís qualifications in order to decide whether to consent to the nomination is ours, and ours alone.Sen. Grassley also said that ìanyone who comes forward with allegations of sexual assault has a right to be heard,î and he wants to give Ford an opportunity to tell her story to the Senate and ìif she chooses, to the American people.îNEW Ltr from @ChuckGrassley to Dr Fordís attorneys encouraging her to appear before the Judiciary Committee regarding the Kavanaugh allegation: pic.twitter.com/GcrEQDTGlPó Frank Thorp V (@frankthorp) September 19, 2018The Iowa senator then said that he also wants to give Judge Kavanaugh an opportunity to respond to the allegations.Chairman Grassley concluded in his letter that Dr. Ford has until Friday morning to inform the Senate Judiciary Committee whether she intends to testify on Monday.Sen. Susan Collins (R-ME), who is considered one of the key swing votes, said in a tweet on Wednesday that she hoped that Ford would reconsider testifying before the committee either in public or private.I hope that Dr. Ford will reconsider and testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Monday. It is my understanding that the Committee has offered to hold either a public or a private session, whichever would make her more comfortable.ó Sen. Susan Collins (@SenatorCollins) September 19, 2018Meanwhile, Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-CA), the ranking member of the Senate Judiciary Committee and the conduit through whom Fordís allegation surfaced, expressed doubts about Fordís accusation on Tuesday.According to Fox News reporter Connor Marley, Feinstein said, ìI canít say that everything is truthful. WASHINGTON, DC ñ Brett Kavanaugh accuser Christine Blasey Ford and her attorney, Debra Katz, demand that the FBI investigate before Ford will speak to senators, which the FBI will not do because it has no jurisdiction, setting the stage for Ford to back out. Republicans are becoming skeptical, with one commenting, ìIt is almost as if the accuser does not want to state her accusations under oath.îRepublicans treated the allegations against President Trumpís Supreme Court nominee seriously, suspending their planned Senate Judiciary Committee vote on his nomination to investigate the matter fully, including setting a time on Monday for both the judge and the woman who accused him of misconduct in 1982 ñ when he was a teenager ñ to provide sworn testimony to senators.Fordís attorney Katz suggested that senators had planned to put Kavanaugh and Ford side-by-side at the same table to testify and rejected that idea as traumatizing to Ford, forcing her to relive the alleged incident.ìContrary to suggestions by Dr. Fordís attorneys, the committee had no plans to place Dr. Ford and Judge Kavanaugh on a panel together, and never indicated plans to do so,î the Senate Judiciary Committee responded in a statement. ìGrassleyís staff offered Dr. Ford multiple dates as well as a choice of providing information in a public or private setting.îNow Katz says that Ford has a new condition before testifying: The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) must investigate this matter first; then Ford would testify afterward.That is a non-starter, the FBI responded. It is a federal law enforcement agency and, therefore, has jurisdiction to investigate only federal crimes. The conduct Ford describes ñ personal sexual misconduct, whether groping or the more serious crime of attempted rape ñ are crimes under state law, not federal law, and, thus, are properly referred to county prosecutors and local police departments, not to the FBI.ìIt is important to remember that an FBI background investigation is entirely different from an FBI criminal investigation,î a former federal prosecutor told Breitbart News. ìThe letter referred by Feinstein has already been added to Kavanaughís file, so the normal background element is complete.îìWhat Ford is now asking for with a full investigation would be a criminal investigation,î the prosecutor continued. ìThe FBI does not do that when there is no federal crime being alleged.îAnother source explains that the purpose of an FBI background investigation is to allow people to provide information in a strictly confidential manner, including secret accusations. Because Ford is making her accusations publicly, there is no role whatsoever for the FBI to play in collecting anonymous or confidential information.The only way the FBI would get involved is if President Trump took the extraordinary action of ordering the FBI to do so. But that creates a no-win situation because then the presidentís opponents who are currently attacking Kavanaugh could accuse the White House of political interference with a law enforcement investigation, directing an agency to act outside its jurisdiction. Some could even call a presidential order for the FBI to investigate a state-law matter to be an abuse of power.Several federal agencies are ìbuzz wordsî in American society, whose very name carries a ìJack Bauerî connotation of serious federal action. Those agencies include the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), the U.S. Secret Service, and the FBI.Saying the FBI is investigating a matter lends immediate gravitas to the situation and, with it, adds political weight to the accusation. Some people are beginning to wonder if Katz or Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-CA) wants the political headline of saying the FBI is investigating Kavanaugh, fully aware that there is nothing for the FBI to investigate within its law enforcement mission.It would also be very difficult to investigate this allegation in any event, as U.S. attorney Joe diGenova said on Fox News on Tuesday, as Ford is now saying she cannot be sure when the event happened, where it happened, or who else was present. The only other individual she named as being present ñ journalist Mark Judge ñ has publicly stated he never saw such a thing, emphatically denying the allegation.ìRepublicans are bending over backwards to defer to the politically powerful #MeToo movement,î Fox Newsís Britt Hume ñ one of the most seasoned political veterans in journalism ñ said on-air Tuesday night.But despite Republicans doing so, some observers believe Ford and Katz are now moving the goalposts in a direction that would delay Kavanaughís joining the Supreme Court†while rejecting the opportunity offered by senators to provide testimony that could get to the bottom of the situation.Senate Republicans are beginning to ask new questions regarding the allegations now that their repeated attempts to get Ford to give sworn testimony are being rejected unless the FBI first takes actions that are outside the agencyís lawful mandate.ìIíve said from the beginning that these are very serious allegations, and she deserves to be heard,î said Sen. Susan Collins (R-ME), a moderate Republican who is a crucial swing vote for Kavanaughís confirmation. ìI really hope she doesnít pass up that opportunityî:Sen. Susan Collins, R-Maine: Iíve said from the beginning that these are very serious allegations, and she deserves to be heard *** I really hope that she doesnít pass up that opportunity."ó Senator John Cornyn (@JohnCornyn) September 19, 2018One Senate staffer ñ though not one affiliated with the Senate Judiciary Committee ñ said in an off-the-record conversation, ìIt is almost as if the accuser does not want to state her accusations under oath.îKen Klukowski is senior legal editor for Breitbart News.
